WRITING.TITLE: HxH is special to many for many reasons, but I realized one thing that it has done that NO other work of fiction has for me.
WRITING.TEXT: I love HxH with all my heart, and there are so many things about the series that resonate with me. But in rewatching the anime, I came to realize something that really set it apart from everything else. I see myself as an amateur writer; even though my skill is not very great this mindset has kept me engaged in stories my entire life. As far back as I can remember, I've had myself wrapped up in some work of fiction. And through all of that none of them- no literature, visual media, comic, or any other form of a fictional story has EVER made me cry at the death of a "villain"... until Hunter X Hunter, of course. I've found antagonists and the like to be compelling, understandable, even love-able in the past, but no book or film has ever caused me to become so moved by them that I shed a tear at their passing. And that is something that HxH has done for me. I know this isn't really that big of a deal for any of you reading this, and not really something that surprises even me... but just realizing this and seeing the fact of it really added to my appreciation for this story... Meruem was an amazing character, and Hunter X Hunter will always be very special to me.

WRITING.TITLE: [Spoilers Extended] A closer look at the consistency of quality in "Game of Thrones", from season one up until now.
WRITING.TEXT: Obviously many think Game of Thrones has dipped in quality lately. This post is just my review and analysis of each season's quality. I'm not here to hate on the show, nor to defend it really. I have no problem with either stance though so feel free to do either (while being civil of course). --- **If you want a TL;DR scroll to the bottom- to the section titled TOTAL REVIEW** --- Before I begin I just want to say that I am even now a big fan of the show, and even my least favorite season is more enjoyable to me than most everything else on tv. A bit obvious and everyone says that, but it holds very true. So, that said I'm going to go through each season chronologically starting from one and review my stance on the quality throughout the show. --- **PART ONE: THE GOOD 'OL DAYS (seasons 1-3)** **Season One:** One may not be my favorite season but I think it is objectively one of the best; being the most faithful to the source material helps, I think. But as a first season in general, it does a great job of introducing everything, especially for a story so large. Everything that eventually made everyone fall in love with the show was there... from the gritty realism and intricacy of the plot to the large world and spread of characters. Add in an excellent cast of dramatic actors and this show broke new ground for live action fantasy. This is where I can nitpick a bit, though. Early on some of the cast were not at their best due to inexperience or just not being extremely comfortable on the show. One example is Kit Harrington; he wasn't "bad", and I love him in later seasons... I think the role was written very generic in season one, and his acting style can be underwhelming in a typical somber protagonist like that. There were a few actors like that in season one though, and just like Kit most of them grew into their respective roles very well as they developed. The acting wasn't the only thing a bit rusty in season one. It honestly felt like the showrunners were still struggling to find their voice of confidence in telling such a unique type of story for the television medium. On top of that this introductory season had to set up such a huge world and story, so while trying to find the show's tone they also had to devote a lot of the pace to introductions and set up, which gave the season's first half a slow feel. All in all, season one definitely shone in it's clever writing and execution (no pun intended) that people tend to miss in the show these days, and remains one of the better seasons in terms of quality to me. It does have a slow pace due to a lot of set up, and some of the acting was not up to par with later seasons. **Season Two:** Season two may actually be my least favorite season, but there are quite a few praises to give before I get too deep into that. First of all, I think the experience and success of season one did wonders in developing a confident tone for the series. The actors as well seemed more comfortable in their roles. Lena, Peter, Nikolaj, Maisie, and many others knocked it out of the park with their respective arcs. On top of that, MOST of the writing was on top form, and they kept the show expanding while remaining intricate and logical. And of course I have to mention the triumph of the season that is "Blackwater", the show's first real battle. It was executed so well as a full episode with great choreography, effects, and performances; it created a brilliant climax for the season. The season is one of my least favorites though, in large part because it feels dangerously close to filler to me. It isn't filler and I'm aware of that, but even though I loved watching it when I finished it just felt like a "bridge" season... like all the good stuff was coming next season. The biggest example of this is Dany's arc. Now granted, the source material was not very eventful for her, but she was a very small part of the second book; also, the mysticism and foreshadowing in her last chapters did a whole lot to make it feel important. Translated to television without most of those elements included, however, and it just felt like something to do for that season with the big stuff happening later. It didn't have much affect on later plots other than showing her dragons had grown a bit, and the tension from the cringey "where are my dragons" conflict never landed. That was all my reaction, anyway. So overall: while the production, acting, dialogue, score, and scope of the show continued to improve, the writing of that particular plot and a constant sense of being a "gateway season" leaves this one to be perhaps my least favorite- though I will admit in terms of general production quality it makes sense the people objectively consider it "better" than some later seasons. **Season Three** Season Three is up there for me. It managed to get the "best" parts of both previous seasons and come out damn close to perfect for me. Unlike many other seasons, no "entire" story arc disappointed me. Generally, both acting AND writing were still improving, too. But apart from that, this season was well paced but stayed extremely eventful throughout with huge developments and shocking twists. Jaime's arc in particular was amazing, and Nikolaj did so damn well in taking that character people hated and making him sympathetic. The Red Wedding was harrowing, and Dany's arc was refreshingly satisfying after season two's mayhem. There are many more triumphs for the season, but overall it kept the standards set by season's one and two and then exceeded them by tossing in the big "game-changer" moments. No season is perfect though, even if this one comes close. I think Theon's "arc" got way too much screen time, mostly because that "arc" was just a solid few episodes of torture for the most part. I love his emotional moments early on, particularly the "my real father" bit. I enjoyed seeing him released and brought back by Ramsay, and even the first torture scene. By then, you felt for Theon at least a little, and got a feel for how much of a psychopath Ramsay was. I don't think we needed so much torture after that, just spread out the earlier scenes and the reveal of who Ramsay is and breakdown of Theon is still effective- if not more so. Another thing that felt weird for me was how underwhelming the finale was. I love season finales in GoT because so much always happens and usually ends up being an amazing mind fuck, and I was waiting for it that season (this may have partially been expectations from the book). I ended up being left with a feeling of "huh, that was it?" I do get that a softer ending made sense after the Red Wedding, and it obviously doesn't hurt the season as a whole too much, but that was the feeling I got and I can't change that. So, in all: I think in some ways, Season Three WAS the peak of the show's quality for me. It was the huge emotional game changer it needed to be and perfected the things that make GoT great: Production/score, amazing performances, brilliant and clever dialogue coupled with intricate and intelligent plots, and huge "WTF moments". Even with some minor personal hang ups, this season is about as close to "perfect" as any season of the show is. **PART ONE REVIEW** I can totally see why people think the show peaked in the first couple seasons. In many ways I agree. While season two is probably my least favorite, seasons one and three are very high up on my list so I can relate to this sentiment. And I do think the writing and dialogue peaked during this time, but there are things in the later seasons that I just love with all my heart. But that leads me into part two. --- **PART TWO: AWKWARD MIDDLE/TRANSITION PHASE (Seasons 4-5)** **Season Four:** When people talk about the "peak" of GoT or when it was "still good", I most often see season four thrown in with the first three. And while it has some amazing moments and brilliant examples of great writing, I feel like this was also the period where they had to accept they were going to pass the books and had to start adjusting the story a lot more. Especially being the middle of the series, they had to take what the series WAS and turn it into what it was going to be. And this season is where I personally started to notice the writing decline. Let's face it, though; when this season was good, god damn was it good. The purple wedding was exceptional, with everything from dialogue and interactions to the performances and tensity later in the sequence being handled beautifully. Then we also have Tyrion's arc- scenes like his trials and eventual confrontation with his father are, in my opinion, big factors that contribute to it being considered the best GoT season. That said, I personally have a few issues with the season. The problem lies in the fact that they adapted the first 2/3 of book three into season three and made a very compelling season out of it. That pretty much left ALL the climaxes of the book for season four- which sounds great on paper. It keeps everything eventful throughout and makes for a season devoted to huge developments. It creates a problem for pacing, though. I feel like they had to create filler, but keep it climactic in tone like everything else in the season. The night's watch going after the mutineers for example; it felt like they needed to stall before the battle, and wanted to have more action in this "action packed" season. I think they started to subconsciously try to one up themselves in violence as the show goes on, particularly with seasons like these. Kind of like Saw; it's a series of movies that focused heavily on plot early on, but later movies- while still having better plots than most horror, seemed to focus more on topping the last film's shock and gore. I think GoT has started to do this from season four until now- not on the same level as Saw for sure, but I just like the example. Season four also has my personal pick for worst written storyline in the show- and yes I hated it more than Dorne. It was Yara's attempt to rescue Reek/Theon. There were better ways to show that Theon had truly become Reek and also to show the iron born move on without him. Way too much time and attention was devoted to setting this up and executing this rescue, and it just felt rushed and out of place. The fight with Ramsay was cringy, how he showed up shirtless and was able to school these armored soldiers up and down. And when he releases the dogs THAT'S game over for Yara and her men? It had a weird feel, made no sense, and kind of just amounted to more filler in the long run. There were a couple other weird moments with these characters for me, a long with more instances of filler and one-upping on being violent. Thankfully, the season still remains fairly high up for me just because of how awesome half the content really is. It seriously does have some of the show's best moments, and those have the trademark intelligence the story had in the first three seasons. It just also contains a lot of the "weirdness" from later seasons. **Season Five** I will admit this is also not one of my favorite seasons, down towards the bottom of the list with season two. I don't want to touch on Dorne too much because I don't have much to say that hasn't been said already. We all know the problems with Dorne. Another thing I wasn't too keen on was that the first half of season five, while having some good moments, reminds me a lot of season two in the sense that it feels like just a bridge from one plot to the next, bordering on filler. Like season two, it wasn't *actually* filler, it was a lot of set up. However from episode 7 onward it was crazy eventful, and in the end I think season five was mostly a set up for seasons six and seven anyway. My big gripe with the season, though, is Jon's "death". I hate to compare to the books because I'm trying to be objective, but the comparison just shows so well how I feel the scene was silly. Now in the book, one big distinction is that the stabbings seem to be a spur of the moment decision. There were a lot of things Jon did to cause the mutiny, allowing the wildlings past the wall was just one of them. But it was the act of breaking his oaths and leading the wildlings south that actually caused this attack. So there didn't seem to be any set plans to mutiny, and when they decided to in that moment there were a ton of reasons, and it actually made sense that they were doing it "for the watch"; since Jon was in the middle of doing the thing the watch hated, killing him may actually have done SOMETHING for their 'cause'. In the show, the only reason seems to be that Jon let the wildlings in. That's it, and they were already saved. The watch couldn't kick them out, they outnumbered them 10/1. And they all owed their lives to Jon Snow, so killing him was stupid. The real kicker to that lack of logic, though... is that they PLANNED this on the show. They got together, set everything up, and killed him. They had the time to think it through, but I guess they thought the wildlings wouldn't be a threat. (And of course, the wildlings fuck their shit up early in the next season). Then they just leave Jon's body there, like "cool we did it, goodnight. what? oh we can burn it later let's just walk off dramatically". Sorry, that's my big rant for the season. But, even with those complaints and some faulty writing, I think the season get's more crap than it deserves. Up until the end, the wall was my favorite storyline for the season and I loved it- Kit stepped it up for his performance that season. I'm also definitely one of those who consider Hardhome to be one of the best episodes ever, too. I even loved Tyrion's travels and meeting Dany- his conversations with Varys and Jorah were a highlight for me. And in retrospect, while they were terrible moments, I don't blame the writers for the Sansa and Shireen moments in the show. I think while they were horrific to watch, they were blown out of proportion a bit. **PART TWO REVIEW** I think seasons four and five are like the "awkward teenage" phase for GoT. They were going off book for the first time, connecting plots and trying to set up the end, while also transitioning the show into something completely different than it was (and I will go into this more in part 3). In general, I would say I like this area of the show less than seasons 1-3, and SO FAR would say that there is a noticeable drop in quality of writing by this point. No surprises there, that's pretty much how EVERYONE feels. However, visually and in terms of musical score, the show is better than ever by this point. The acting is also better than ever. --- **PART THREE: MODERN GAME OF THRONES (Season 6-Now)** **Season Six:** First, I want to go over a couple factors that make season six very interesting. I mentioned when talking about the fifth season that it was mostly set up for seasons six and seven. So the set up is already done here, but also this is the first season to completely pass the books. What I'm getting at is that with only a shortened season 7 and shorter season 8 left, the true climax starts in season six, and with all the set up done the "awkward transition" has ended. We have now left what the show WAS and what it is going to be. So yes, the writing has not hit the high-points of seasons 1-3 again, nor is it likely to do so again. But, that's not the only strength the show had. These characters have already been fleshed out, and even if there are some inconsistencies from time to time there are STILL pretty much no characters like them in visual media, and I think THAT is a big part of what keeps the show so high up there for me. The world and characters have had fifty episodes to flesh them out, and now I'm beyond invested. Season six was the payoff for everything that was set up so far, and got the endgame started. And for me, it was extremely satisfying. Now, season six wasn't big on surprises, it bordered on formulaic, and in a lot of ways the developments played it very safe... it still might be my favorite season. The biggest reason for this is the emotional pay off of the season. It's predictable but that's partly because so much of what is happening has been set up for five seasons. And when they perform and direct these scenes well, it is godly. Like when Sansa and Jon reunited... with no dialogue there was SO MUCH emotion in just their faces, the music, and the camera shots. There were so many other emotional moments in this season that were pulled off so well- the ending to "The Door", Dany uniting the Dothraki, the R+L=J feeding into the KITN scene, and so many others... the pure pay off and emotion made this season my favorite. Not everything was superb, the pacing was a bit weird in episodes 6-8 for me, and I was definitely not a fan of the writing in Arya's braavos arc; it felt inconsistent and made the faceless men look way less serious than they should. Nothing unique there, I'm sure my complaints on that arc are very similar to countless others seen here. But that was my only large issue with season six. Sure, it was predictable in a lot of ways. But it delivered more than half of my favorite moments in the show and took us to where I was wanting to be from season one, and damn did it bring a tear to my eye doing it. **Season Seven:** I know this season isn't over yet, but with only one episode left and with all of this fresh on my mind I want to include it; I may update this when the finale airs. So Season Seven is another mixed bag for me, but is honestly probably in my top 3 still. The writing is more like seasons 4-5 for me, there are a lot of inconsistencies and a few outright plot-holes. More than there were in season six. However, I am loving seeing all of these characters come together. So many amazing interactions: Dany and Varys, Dany and Jon, Arya and Sansa and Bran, Bran and fking Littlefinger (chaos is a ladder!), Tyrion and Jaime, everyone from the seven who went beyond the wall... I could go on and on. It's the characters, and that brings me to the Field of Fire... that's what I still think makes this show great. Yes, it's transitioned from being subtly political and quietly clever to being an all out fantasy war, but we still have these complex characters fighting in it... ones that have been built through endless development and all of those complex plot's we've seen- all of that is coming out of them in these new battles, and FoF was great for this reason. We finally get to see the dragons tear apart a Lannister army, it's fanstasy af, but we have these two truly humanized and developed sides on the exchange. And while much of what made the show clever is not there, this is STILL breaking new ground for fantasy. So with some sloppy writing noted, the characters alone make this season very high up for me. Since it's not over, I don't have much more to say now, but as mentioned above I very well may add more to this when season seven ends. **PART THREE REVIEW:** After going over where the show is now, I have to say that while the show's writing may have peaked in season three, it has a different but valuable quality that's peaking now. After season three there was a decline for me in writing and keeping the world consistent. However, the phase of GoT we are at now is something new... and being that I enjoy reading and writing myself I KNOW that writing is super important, and I miss that tightness that it had in the beginning very much. But the writing isn't TERRIBLE now, it's just not as full-proof in preventing holes and inconsistencies as earlier seasons. Now it does about as well as most decent television does for that. I know that having that smart writing that was above everything else was what made so many people love the show, but it's got to be hard to maintain that level when adapting such complicated books- and not being able to read the last couple. But apart from that, the show still has a lot that other shows don't, and I'm not talking about visual effects or production values. As I have said, the characters have already had so much development. I know everyone has the gripes on certain character growth (like many of you, I hate how much they have flopped with Jaime's development), but for the most part we have these detailed, flawed, and full characters involved in this "great war" that's coming. I think one of the biggest things that turns people off of "new" GoT is the idea that it is not a clever show of political intrigue that defies all fantasy tropes anymore- that it is becoming the fantasy trope it was originally dissecting. This is understandable, and it is a big part of what made GoT so special to begin with. But as I mentioned before, by developing these human characters in the very subtle and HUMAN conflict in the first half of the series, I think the show is and will continue to dissect those tropes by putting these fully realized characters in the middle of all of this high fantasy conflict. I think that will play a huge role in the end of the show, but for now I can see a huge difference in most high fantasy and this story, even as it is in the tv show now. You would be hard pressed to find a fantasy series that could pull off the character depth of Jaime's charge on Dany in the Field of Fire, or the heartbreaking "hold the door" revelation. Though it is sad that we lost that subtle writing from before, we still have these characters keeping this show fresh. The story was always going to shift from the political conflict to a supernatural war, the set up was in the very first scene of the show- and in the very first chapter of the books. So that's why I have a hard time saying the show peaked in season three: there was so much done so right in that season and it had that incredible writing that we know and love, but I honestly don't think it holds much weight in the character depth of those we still have left in seasons six and seven, or how these characters are influencing fate and the great wars to come. --- **TOTAL REVIEW:** **Again, this is just from my POV, not trying to make these sound like "objective facts".** * **No season of GoT is perfect. Earlier seasons that adapted the books more closely generally had better writing, but had some of the same types of issues from time to time that newer seasons have.** * **I do miss the subtle and clever nature of the political conflict from earlier seasons, and without source material to adapt I do feel like the writing can get sloppy at times, now. These two factors definitely contribute to the feeling that the show is declining in some ways.** * **That said, I'm okay with the change into a more 'high fantasy' conflict because we always knew it was coming, and I think the characters have more than enough depth to keep the show fresh and unique no matter how deep the fantasy elements go.** * **The rockiest part of the series for me is the middle- seasons 4 and 5 struggle with the new task of working off book and transitioning the series into a different form. This results in more mixed bags so to speak- some storylines being much more compelling than others.** * **Character strength in the past couple seasons have kept me very invested in the show, and I think watching these characters come to power, collide, and meet their fate is as appealing for me in it's own way as the intrigue of earlier seasons was.** **Overall, the show has never stopped having amazing moments, and has also never been perfect; while I have personal preferences of seasons or stories, as it progresses some strengths get better and some issues get worse. It's a matter of personal preference, and for me the weaknesses of the new episodes are made up for by it's strengths.** **And for shit's and giggles, my current rankings for all seven seasons of Game of Thrones:** **Season Six gt; Season Three gt; Season Seven gt; Season One gt; Season Four gt; Season Five gt; Season Two** --- --- --- **EDIT: POSTED THIS IN A COMMENT, BUT I'LL PUT IT IN THE POST TOO:** **I just wanted to thank you guys. I didn't think I'd get much feedback at all, but I actually got a lot! And like 95% of it has been supportive and super rational and friendly discussion about difference in opinion. I hate to admit it, but I did not expect to find that here. To to majority of you who disagreed but were willing to explain why and not be a dick about it; you are the best kind of person, and the world needs more of you. Thank you for giving me a ton more faith in this fandom. Love you guys!**

WRITING.TITLE: While we continue to wait for hiatus to end, those of few of you who have not yet checked out Boku No Hero Acadamia SHOULD.
WRITING.TEXT: I realize the anime has gotten a respectable popularity for it, particularly with season two finishing up now. But, to those of you who have NOT yet seen it, I wanted to say that it fills a couple holes left by HxH and is similar in many ways while also remaining very much its own thing. I don't intend to get into any spoilers- and I'm a couple episodes behind on the new season, which still has yet to air the final two episodes. I do want to explain a bit more why I recommend this anime as a HxH fan. First off, I think HxH is a god damn masterpiece- it is beyond a doubt in my top 5 anime (possibly top 3), is by a long shot my favorite shounen, and has cemented itself in one of my favorite pieces of media in general. While Boku No Hero Academia (which I will refer to as BnH for simplicity's sake) has not quite hit that level yet, I haven't enjoyed a show that is at least loosely a shounen since Magi and HxH. I saw the first season a month or two back, and already enjoyed it. It was easily an 8/10 for me, which I like to think of as my "no regrets" level of rating. May not be perfect or have some "wow" factor to boost it to a 9, but not a single episode was one that I did not enjoy. I felt the urge to binge a bit (like HxH), and when it was over I already considered it to be a modern classic in a lot of ways, even if it hadn't become one of my favorites yet. But I started season two a couple of days ago, and woah am I getting into it. In like three days, I have watched 21 episodes. Now this doesn't seem like a lot, since episodes are short and anime is super easy for most of us to binge... but these past three days I have been working at a restaurant from about 2 in the afternoon until after midnight- a long with obligations outside of work and a social life (went out to a bar with a few work friends night before last). I still managed to binge the majority of this season. It has gotten a bit deeper than I expected, and is easily becoming at least a 9/10 for me. Now, those similarities to HxH that I mentioned? Without going too much into the plot, BnH is a shounen that is not afraid to step away from those shounen tropes from time to time. Not on the same deconstructionalist levels of HxH, maybe (yet) but it is apparent that it is not afraid to do what's right for the story rather than fulfill specific fantasies a typical shounen audience might have. I see this particularly in the main character: so far, while perhaps not having the same amount of potential for psychological depth as Gon (again, YET- I'll address this near the end), the show definitely makes a point to show that he is the underdog here- definitely building up to be a very strong character, but the show is doing an extremely good job of making this feel earned in my opinion, and it is not going to be immediate satisfaction in terms of getting him where he needs to be. The development and "training" is very entertaining though, and I am loving the ride there. Another prominent example is that they are not afraid to let the MC lose from time to time. It's also a similar situation where the MC has "potential" to rival every single character (for the most part), he is currently outclassed by most people who are serious "fighters". This brings up another similarity to HxH- the characters: While I doubt the supporting characters will get the level of focus in HxH (to the point of not even having the main character involved in major events), there is certainly an incredibly massive cast of unique characters, a great many of whom seem to be getting a decent amount of character to development. The power system, while not by any means as detailed or thought out as HxH, does end up with a similar result of having a TON of characters each possessing very specific and unique abilities that give insight into their personality and provides endless possibilities for combat, match-ups of opponents and in some cases team-mates, and the strategy involved with the former two points. Like I said, it's far more simple than the Nen system, but the feeling of seeing new characters unique "powers" revealed definitely gives me a similar feeling to the way HxH handled that very concept. Particularly when there are so many characters after less than 40 episodes, and I definitely get the impression that as the series progresses there will be a lot more. And quite a few of been given a lot of development, attention, and history. Now this is my opinion, but I will say I don't feel like any character has reached the compelling level of development or backstory of HxH... yet lol. Which brings me to explain why I feel it's been so necessary to add those "yets" to certain things. I see a TON of potential for growth in this anime. The second season addressed a lot of stuff and went a lot deeper into existing things than I had expected from the first season- while certain aspects of the show are very simple, it appears that the story itself is not afraid to grow more complex and get a bit "deeper" than the surface level the beginning of the show reveals (again, this is reminiscent of HxH). In fact, when you consider that it has not yet hit 40 episodes yet, the amount of characters and their respective development and certain story aspects is actually very impressive. If it has the amount of time to grow, it seriously may rival HxH after 100+ episodes for me... now HxH is incredibly special for me, and if I were to be honest I would say I don't expect to love it quite that much, but I 100% expect it to at least reach for that mark and become one of my all-time favorites- I'd say after 35ish episodes it's already a favorite of mine. On that note, I've actually heard that the latest arc in the manga has a certain "Chimera Ant" quality to it... I only saw this in one person's reddit comment (on this sub actually), so I'm not sure how much truth there is to this, but it has DEFINITELY piqued my interest- the CA arc was a significant portion of what makes HxH so incredible to me. And this makes me want to read the manga for BnH, too. Like Berserk and HxH, I could already see it being the type of manga that I would really enjoy reading- even parts I've already seen in the anime. So, sorry if this gets brought up more than I've seen around here, and again if most of you have already seen the anime; I'm sure a great many of you have. But I'm getting so into it, and with the HxH vibes I get from time to time, I just wanted to put this out there just in case anyone who is possibly interested can just get this additional enthusiastic recommendation from someone who shares a love for HxH. All of that said, the ways this show reminds me of HxH is not over-the-top: while there are a few things I've specifically noted, for the most part I wouldn't GENERALLY say the show is "like HxH". In fact, in the first season, I thought of a few other shows it reminded me of first: One Punch Man, Kill la Kill (much less on that vibe for me now), and "DanMachi" are just a couple episodes. All in all, it definitely has it's own vibe and is worth checking out for far more reasons than the similarities to HxH. Also, I'm very sorry for the length of this post- that tends to happen with me. I suppose the right thing to do is add a TLDR, so here goes. **---** **TL;DR-** My Hero Academia is at least loosely a shounen anime, but one that has done a couple unexpected things to set itself apart from other anime of the same genre. The main character has a huge focus of having to "earn" his power and is not OP for the sake of being OP, and he is surrounded by an impressively large cast of colorful and unique characters; many with a fair amount of development and focus and an individual "power". After a binge of most of season two, I am really impressed with it's direction and already LOVE it- I think it's going to achieve great things in the long run. I think you should check it out, especially you guys since you like HxH- we could easily have very similar tastes in what appeals to "these" kinds of anime. **---** Other than all that, a big thank you to those of you who read any of this. If just one person sees this and watches this anime to their own enjoyment, then I can't ask for anymore. :) To those of you who HAVE seen it, feel free to talk about it! Do you agree/disagree with my assessments here? To those that have read the manga ahead of where the anime is, do you have any comments on my assumptions of the potential of where the story is headed? Remember that I am still a couple episodes from being caught up on season two (though I will most likely watch those tonight), and would generally like to avoid specific spoilers for the manga since I intend to read it once I finish this season. I'm not too worried about minor details about future plot points, but to be safe if you want to go into that maybe tag as spoilers for other people's sake. Thanks again, and hope that some of you enjoy the anime!

WRITING.TITLE: So, about the whole business of shooting "fake" scenes to throw off spoilers...
WRITING.TEXT: I'm kind of confused by this. I know this was a couple weeks back that HBO mentioned this, but it keeps popping up on my mind. Are spoilers really THAT big of a deal? Were they seriously intending on doing this? I mean, wouldn't filming "fake" scenes take up a portion of the show's precious budget and almost more importantly time? It's already going to be an extra long wait for the final season, and MOST fans don't even read the spoilers, and far far far FAR less actively take part in uncovering them. To waste the show's budget and take up more time (even if it's minimal) just to ATTEMPT to throw off leaks that most people won't read just seems like a dick move to the fanbase of the show. Alright, ignoring the fact that anyone who is close enough to the production to be able to leak a full out synopsis of the season complete with scene descriptions that have actual dialogue and character emotion would MOST LIKELY also know which scenes are fake... There still would be some stuff that's obvious. For example, a huge scene with the Army of the Dead or an insane battle sequence would be WAY too expensive to shoot fake scenes, so if we get any production leaks of this we can assume that's real. It not only seems far from foolproof or even that likely to succeed, but is kind of insulting to the people already working so hard on the show to put them through that and also a middle finger to the majority of fans who may have to wait longer just because HBO is butthurt they're "extra security" wasn't working. Maybe I over estimate how much time and money it would take to do this, but it still seems like a huge waste of effort and really just plain stupid. I still expect to be get reliable leaks for the next season, and all this action would do is make me think less of HBO. If they even go through with it, I really do think that it's so dumb of an idea that there's a chance they're just blowing smoke cause they're pissed and won't actually doing anything. I mean am I just being stupid and some less than reliable sources or missed some sarcasm in the statement? Or am I just putting too much thought into it? The idea of it kinda just built up this little rant in me, I guess.

WRITING.TITLE: Any tips on conveying closeness and deep friendship between two characters?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm working on a story that will begin with a main character who's best friend from years ago returns into his life. His friend will reveal what he's been up to and include the main character in this "situation", which will be the main focus of the story. However, much of this will rely heavily establishing how strong their friendship was and how close they still are, and how this is strained by the friends new obsessions and they start drifting apart. I'm really enthusiastic about this story, but this pulling this off well is crucial to making it work; and this will require two of what I feel like are my weakest points as a writer: 1) Writing "casual" dialogue 2) Conveying strong bonds between friends without being over the top about it- basically using subtlety to show their relationship. The first one is a big part of what throws me off in STARTING stories... Typically I'll want to set up the main characters and their relationships before introducing the main conflict, which needs a lot of "casual dialogue" so to speak. The characters just talking about everyday life, often the idea is for the dialogue to serve the purpose of establishing the nature of their relationships. For some reason, though, I'm really bad at writing normal everyday discussions. It always seems so "cringey" to me. A lot of that is probably normal for writers, particularly in a first draft, but still I just feel totally at a loss on how best to go about this. In this situation, I think I want to jump pretty much right into the story from the beginning; with perhaps the first scene being the reunion of the two characters and the old friends explanation of where he has been, and by extension the general plot of the story itself. I struggle much less for dialogue when it is wrapped up deeply in the story, and on top of that I think this is a natural starting place. Other than the friendship of these characters, going back earlier doesn't have much to do with the plot of this story (at least the way I have it in my head currently). But that leaves me with the task of using the dialogue between them to show how close they have been. Of course as they continue to interact throughout the story their time together will help towards this as well, but I feel like their initial moments should be a very significant step in cementing all of this. I know practice and a lot of work writing and re-writing will go a long way in addressing my weaknesses here, but I was wondering if any of you have some general tips that may be helpful. Thank you to anyone who takes the time to read this! Any insight is appreciated greatly!

WRITING.TITLE: [Possible Season 3 Spoilers] I think the passing of time is very favorable on Rick and Morty
WRITING.TEXT: For the first part of this season I wasn't coming to this sub much, but from what I gather there was a fair amount of sentiment that this was a weak season... especially before the break (and the infamous "Ricklantis" episode). Now, I've been enjoying this season since the first episode- but if I really think about it I might have agreed with that sentiment a couple weeks ago. For the first few episodes I sort of felt like season two had already achieved more in my mind by the same point in season three. Granite, I really loved Pickle Rick and Rest and Ricklaxation, but I kept thinking about Mortynight Run and Total Rickall, not to mention the infamous ending of Autoerotic Assimilation. While I was really enjoying season three, it just didn't feel like it was there so to speak. That said, I feel like I've come to realize something about the way I appreciate Rick and Morty. I binged season one and loved it, and got to tune in every week for season two. And watching it weekly, it dawned on me the other day that I had a very similar experience that I did for most of this current season. I remember loving a couple episodes, but thinking it was not as strong overall as the first season. However, as time passed and the season was over, I feel like letting the episodes sink in over that time made me appreciate them so much more. I don't even remember how it happened, but at some point I actually came to like season two more than season one. Both seasons had episodes I was less entertained by: for season one, the couple that come to mind are Anatomy Park and Raising Gazorpazorp. In two, it would be episodes like Look Who's Purging Now or maybe Interdimensional Cable 2. All of the above episodes are funny, and there really isn't an episode of the show I actively dislike, but those just seem more forgettable to me. However season two in particular had so many episodes that would be ranked super high for me: Big Trouble in Little Sanchez, Total Rickall, Mortynight Run, and The Ricks Must Be Crazy are all huge favorites of mine. The point, though, is that while they were coming out every week I didn't exactly feel that way. And already as we near the end of this season, I feel like I'm appreciating the strength of the episodes more and more. Rest and Ricklaxation I absolutely adored, and the past three episodes have been incredible- as cliche as it sounds these days, I really think The Ricklantis Mixup is my favorite episode of the entire series. Maybe with such build up of hype for new seasons along with having to watch them one at a time with at least a week in between is affecting my ability to appreciate this show- and the test of time is how I truly determine where these seasons stand for me. I already feel that a few weeks from now I will see this as a very strong season indeed. Just the past couple weeks have me loving even the earlier episodes of the season even more. Anyone else experience something similar in watching the show? In the sense that the more time passes the better the episodes hold up. I can only speak for myself, and I don't think most people are criticizing this season as much as they were a few weeks back, but where do you stand on this season: weak or strong?

WRITING.TITLE: I ranked the thirty-one episodes in order from my least favorite to my personal fave (spoilers)
WRITING.TEXT: Yep, I'm a loser who has a bit too much time on my hands, and because of that I actually threw in a few thoughts on each episode too. Figured we could use a break from the McDonalds posts anyway (but I'll still take this little opportunity to say fuck McDonalds). Obviously this is based on my enjoyment of the episodes, and not an attempt to objectively claim which ones are best. Also worth noting that I don't dislike any episode of the show, I could literally play any of them and enjoy it. **Note: I will have some spoilers in my descriptions. Probably shouldn't look through this unless you've seen everything or don't care about spoilers. If you just don't care about my thoughts behind this (can't blame ya too much), the episodes and their rank are in bold.** Here we go. From thirty-one (least favorite) to the top dog. **Thirty-One: 2x08 Interdimensional Cable 2: Tempting Fate** Something had to come in last place, but I didn't have as many issues with this as some people did. I think a lot of the television "clips" were fucking hysterical, about as much as the first interdimensional episode. However, with the novelty worn off and a less appealing story tying the clips together, it still falls below. **Thirty: 1x07 Raising Gazorpazorp** As I've said I enjoy all the episodes, so for a lot of the ones near the bottom of the list it comes down to memorability, or how much the episode "stands out". This episode is great (I particularly love the family gags when Morty brings the sex robot home), it just happens to be one of those episodes with the least amount to set aside for me. **Twenty-Nine: 3x10 The Rickchurian Mortydate** This episode is strange. The expectations for a finale to be a "big" one didn't really play into this ranking, but to be honest the first half of this episode just didn't land for me. The jokes seemed a bit weird and is probably the closest an episode has come to being "boring" for me so far. However, I did really enjoy the attempts to kill Rick by the president's men (and their disastrous results). There was also some great moments for the characters in the Smith family in the end. These high notes weren't incredibly impressive compared to what the show has done in the past, but it saved itself from being my least favorite episode. **Twenty-Eight: 1x03 Anatomy Park** Again, this is a fun episode that just ends up being less memorable for me. Some great moments of humor (particularly the end with the giant hovering hobo) aside, it's not a big one for standing out to me. **Twenty-Seven: 1x04 M. Night Shaym-aliens** This and the next couple episodes fall into a similar category of standing out less with no real faults, so I'm just gonna go over some highlights for them- it's funny how even my least favorite episodes have some great quotes and moments. I loved the simulation jokes ("My Man! Slow down!"... The toaster bit, "you sure you haven't seen that before, Morty?"), but the part of this episode that resonates the most with me is pretty obvious: watching Rick come out on top after all of the back and forth mindfuckery was hella satisfying. **Twenty-Six: 2x09 Look Who's Purging Now** I haven't seen the purge, so I honestly don't know if I'd appreciate this episode more with that context. I'm familiar enough with the premise to find it funny, though. I loved the song choice when they start the killing spree, and the old man's ominous hints and the crazy stuff he intends to do during the purge. **Twenty-Five: 3x02 Rickmancing the Stone** The plotline with Morty and that serial killers arm alone carried this episode for me in a very positive way. All the jokes landed, from the "this isn't over" bit to the casual way he drowned that guy near the end. On top of that, it was a great start for the character development Morty received in season three, which is one of my favorite things about the recent season. **Twenty-Four: 1x11 Ricksy Business** And just like that, we're out of the episodes I just find less memorable and the hard part begins: comparing the episodes that *do* stand out. While this one wasn't some big crazy finale, the big party allowed for some great moments and of course the big dimensional hop. It also introduced bird person which adds to it's credit, and he marks his entrance with his infamous insight into Rick's mental state. **Twenty-Three: 1x02 Lawnmower Dog** It says a lot that already loved Rick and Morty after just the first two episodes of the show. The inception style dream subplot was full of great stuff, but the Snuffles/Snowball story was a damn good follow up to the pilot. It wasn't the most insane plot they have done, but I loved the way they executed it with just a slight hint of darkness... "Where are my testicles, Summer?" Delivered coldly by a Snuffles towering over her in the dark is an all-time favorite quote from the show. **Twenty-Two: 1x01 Pilot** Such a great opener for the show. It did a fantastic job of introducing all the great elements of the show: it had plenty of great low-brow jokes from "Principal Vagina" to stick mega seeds up Morty's butt, since his butthole was still taut but malleable. It also had a bit of the existential humor (the coughed up being that is born, lives, and dies as they run away with Rick just shouting "Don't think about it!") and a few good tastes of the show's darkness, like when Morty kills the bureaucrat and Rick's psychotic monologue over a convulsing Morty in the end. It would probably be even higher on this list if later episodes didn't have the advantage of a bit more depth established for the characters and a better overall sense of the show's tone. **Twenty-One: 1x09 Something Ricked This Way Comes** One of the only episodes that deals with the "supernatural" and I loved the context they used for this. I thought the character of the devil was hilarious and really enjoyed his relationship with Summer. The concept of his feud with Rick was straight up brilliant, though; everything from the way he "invented" ways around the curses to how he just got so deep under the devils skin and then got bored when he won, proving he was a bigger dick than Satan himself. Plus there's the added bonus of Rick and Summer beating up the devil in the end, along with a nazi and a dog-kicker. **Twenty: 3x04 Vindicators 3: The Return of Worldender** On the surface, I might have guessed that I would rank this lower. However, this episode has a lot going for it to get a certain level of love for me. For some reason, all the scenes with Noob-Noob in the beginning killed me. It had no reason to be as funny as it was. So much humor that shouldn't have landed somehow managed to make me weak in the whole episode. The way they teased some real human emotion from Rick to end in a Noob-Noob reveal/joke was perfect. This episode has a big highlight, though, and it seems to be recurring throughout the third season: Morty's development. He's so used to Rick's crap by this point that he can go through every single obstacle with very little thought. On top of that we can see his naivety slowly slipping away and the start of a cynicism that borders on "Rick level". In particular I loved that he is at a point where he is disarming Ricks drunken neutrino bombs. "Too many", as he points out furiously. **Nineteen: 3x05 The Whirly Dirly Conspiracy** The Rick and Jerry episode worked well, and the conflict between the two brought up some really natural plot points and character moments. The "immortality field" also had some great (and fucked up) humor. I also really loved everything with Morty, Beth, and Summer. This was another great episode for highlighting the character growth of Morty, particularly how desensitized he is growing to all of the craziness. He actually seems to go to a pretty dark place when he confronts the guy who made summer self-conscious... it's also worth nothing that it was never shown what happens between them and the "reverse-y" machine thing Morty had pointed at the guy. We also got a decent glimpse at Beth's own brand of crazy. **Eighteen: 2x01 A Rickle in Time** A really solid premier for the second season that feeds off the first season's finale really well. The hypothetical time humor may be a bit silly but it made for some excellent moments. The first season had some great character development for sure, but I think it makes sense that more of that would come from seasons two and three, and this episode starts that off pretty well. Particularly the big moment when Rick sacrifices himself for Morty- that is until he realizes it's possible to live and begs God to live, then saves himself with a big "fuck you" to the big man. Plus the Einstein post-credit scene is funny as fuck. **Seventeen: 2x02 Mortynight Run** Rick and Morty is quite often very clever, but there a couple of instances where it is not only clever but just really brilliant in the context of the established universe. There are so many possibilities to play with when you are dealing with alternate realities and a genius who can interact with them all, and some gimmicks that the show uses just come out flawless: I think the Jerry daycare is one of those things that is just absolutely brilliant within the context of the show, and as a result all the related humor hits so welll. This episode also has Blips and Chitz, which leads to Roy; Morty's confusion upon returning after living an entire life in a video game just made this "joke" or whatever it was work so well. Then of course we have the "fart", with some great trippy music scenes. I particularly love the scene where the fart causes the deaths of an entire fleet of police-ships while Rick and Morty just watch in shock. Accompanied by the catchy "moonmen" song, I felt this scene was really effective. **Sixteen: 3x09 The ABCs of Beth** This episode is mostly ranked higher for it's fantastic attention to Beth's character; it very much succeeded in showing some disturbing insight to her mental state, which season three had already brought into question. Everything in Froopyland was fantastically fucked up, too. I've seen some criticism for the dialogue, but personally I loved the "heart to heart" between Beth and Rick in the end, and the decision not to confirm if Beth is a clone or not was definitely the right call. Also I have to mention Morty again in this episode... I loved how knowledgeable he is about the race that Jerry's partner belongs to, another prime example in season three of how much Morty has grown through his adventures with Rick. **Fifteen: 2x10 The Wedding Squanchers** The best finale of the three existing seasons, this episode goes big for the last half of the episode. The insight of Rick's past with the galactic federation, the resulting relationship with his friends, the death of Bird Person and his ultimate arrest made for a big episode. It may have been even higher on the list, but ultimately this episode works as a big climactic episode to end a season, and is in a lot of ways "undone" by the next season. Which is for the best since Rick and Morty works so well as an episodic show. **Fourteen: 2x05 Get Schwifty** This episode obviously has a lot to offer. It spawned so much for the fandom that it has to have a decent ranking. We got the get schwifty song, the "show me what you got" memes, a lot of satire on the state of religion, and quite simply the best Ice T jokes the world has created yet. Water T and the Rise of the Numbericrons will inevitably be the greatest story of a hero we will ever see. **Thirteen: 2x03 Auto Erotic Assimilation** A great episode in general, but it is in the top half of these episodes mostly because it offers more insight into the already established depression that Rick deals with. His unhealthy relationship with Unity has some deeper implications if you pay attention, but no matter what you notice the ending of the episode shoves all of this into your face without mercy. The final scene where Rick gets just trashed, pulls out a being that seems to be in pain and destroys it, and is about to do the same to himself but is too intoxicated and just passes out was one of the most emotional moments of the entire show. The song choice was perfect, too. **Twelve: 1x05 Meeseeks and Destroy** While this may not be the most clever or the most emotional episode, it does offer some of both. The Meeseeks gimmick may not scream "wit", but the idea behind it and the resulting situation is a pretty clear mark of creativity. As far as the Rick and Morty adventure, the bathroom scene with Mr. Jellybean may be disturbing but it is a nice moment to see that Rick genuinely cares about Morty and goes out of his way to make things alright for him. I also loved all of the nonsense in that tavern. Overall, though, it is the idea behind the Meeseeks box that works so well... for some reason. Somehow, it managed to create a story full of insanity and quotable moments that make this episode one of the most entertaining and memorable so far. **Eleven: 1x08 Rixty Minutes** Another episode that is brilliant within this universe: a box that allows access to channels from every conceivable reality and the absurd amount of random fuckery it provides- now that is a great concept. Now use that to create a series of one-off clips to showcase the improvisational abilities of the writes and an existential storyline behind those watching it to tie everything together... and you have a straight up brilliant episode. The scene with Morty and Summer is amazing. It's just a huge added bonus that some of those television bits are the funniest things I have ever seen. **Ten: 2x04 Total Rickall** This episode is top ten worthy to me for it's humor alone. The memory embedding parasites were a great idea, and Mr. Poopy Butthole has become an iconic character for the show. This episode had a rapid-fire method of humor that worked crazy well for me. There are too many awesome bits that come to mind to mention many of them, it was pretty much the whole episode and it's pacing. The ending, though, when Beth shoots Mr. Poopy Butthole and he just bleeds out, real as shit... What can I even say. Going from that to the shot of Beth downing a bunch of wine shaking violently is possibly my favorite cut to credits scene. **Nine: 2x06 The Ricks Must Be Going Crazy** The fact that this episode is based around Rick going into the world he created to power his battery is already insane. I love the repetition of each scientist creating a new world as a source for power and all of the resulting stuff. The best material of this episode is honestly Summer waiting in the ship, which has the "keep summer safe" protocol active. Of course it gets dark real quick by maiming and killing people, but as soon as the restriction is made not to cause physical harm it shows that psychological methods can get just as dark. The true humor of this episode, and what makes it an all-timer for me, is how much the ship inevitably does to "keep Summer safe" while obeying her wishes the entire time. Well, that and Morty's time with the Tree People. **Eight: 2x07 Big Trouble in Little Sanchez** This one is another classic. Beth and Jerry's marriage counseling was good, and I died when that psychedelic other-wordly "goddess Beth" appeared. But most people remember this episode because of Tiny Rick, and rightfully so- this episode is his. So much great material just by putting him in the spotlight, and ultimately revealing his subconscious cries for help. And God help me, when he returns to his body and just starts going at all his other "bodies" with axe- fully naked and getting blood all over himself and his mortified grandchildren- THAT... I just loved that. **Seven: 3x06 Rest and Ricklaxation** This has my favorite opening scene. The "in-and-out" adventure and the resulting chaos all leads up to that break down in the ship. Morty just starts crying, but that primal scream from Rick is when you know shit is real. It makes so much sense in terms of where the characters are while remaining both funny and a little dark. So they go on a vacation, which leads to one of my favorite plotlines. They separate the part of them they view as toxic from the rest of them, creating to sentient beings for one person. This just adds so much insight to each character while creating crazy and hysterical situations at the same time. Obviously a big feature of this is that it shows the extent of how much Rick cares for Morty, and how he views this as a toxic weakness. Another interesting thing to see is how Morty- who has lived his whole life being looked down on and not valued much- acts when his toxic anxiety and self-esteem issues are removed. This doesn't lead to any big revelation of his character, but it is very interesting to see how he starts to act. Especially in a season full of character development for him... I'm really starting to think Morty's character is going to head in a dark direction somewhere in the series future, especially considering that "Evil Morty" is actually a thing. **Six: 3x08 Morty's Mind Blower's** I think they learned their lesson after the second interdimensional cable: random one offs can be a humorous tool, but the novelty of that particular idea has long worn off and on top of that viewers still need something decent and cohesive to string everything together. I think this was a brilliant answer to this need, The idea of using time's that Morty's mind had been wiped as a source for some "one offs" not only opened the door to a decent episode arc to tie the clips together but also gave a unique spin to the clips themselves... and by limiting themselves to that concept I think they allowed themselves more creativity in a lot of ways- of course that is while remaining a lot more relevant to the show itself. A lot of the clips were amazing- the squirrels, moon man, floop-floopian, and the alien torture to name a few- but I loved the wedge the memories drove between the titular characters and the questions it raised... like just how far has Rick's control over Morty's life gone? Then the twist of them losing their memories in the middle of the viewings allowed them to try to establish their relationship by doing nothing other than keep watching the memories. Of course, this being his only context, Morty has an existential breakdown and Rick is inspired by this; so they form a suicide pact. All of this leads up to Summer's perfect delivery of "You guys doing Morty's Mind Blowers?" and the eventual "Oh man, it's a scenario four." This episode offers a great spin on a familiar concept and gives us awesome insights into Rick and Morty themselves, at the same time giving some top notch humor. It ends with an awesome character moment for Summer and a return to "normal". **Five: 3x03 Pickle Rick** The pickle rick episode was highly anticipated, and as expected there was more to him just being a "pickle". Although the simplicity of this "random" change was definitely put to good use as a joke. The psychological aspect of the characters was put center stage for this, and the pay off was amazing. We got such a deep look into where each of the characters in the episode were in terms of their psyche and it wasn't exactly pretty. This was a really good play for an episode early in a season based around this exact type of themes. By the end, in true Rick and Morty fashion, things got dark when Beth and Rick finally let their feelings out... and slightly darker when you realize Morty and Summer never got to. **Four: 3x01 The Rickshank Rickdemption** Season Three started off very high. Just to name a few things, we got a tease at Rick's back story, the schezuan sauce bit, the reveal that Rick's backstory was just a way of fucking with the federation and his way of breaking out of prison, the collapse of the council of Ricks at our Rick's hand, and his manipulation of the family- causing a season arc of sorts revolving around divorce and imposing his will on others to put himself on top. **Three: 1x10 Close Rick-Counters of the Rick Kind** The introduction of the council of Ricks: this is a big one. The concept was great, and the conflict between our Rick and Morty and the "evil" Rick and Morty made for a very entertaining episode. This is also one of the first episodes where we see just how much Rick cares about Morty, whether he admits it or not. All of this was done well enough to put the episode super high up on its own merit, but the ending reveal that the Rick was being controlled by "Evil Morty", who seems to be an evil genius with his own motives, was executed incredibly. That song, tho... **Two: 1x06 Rick Potion #9** This was when I knew the show would be an all time favorite for me. A classic if a bit generic Rick and Morty premise which blows up as usual is apparently the plot. But things just get worse and worse, no matter what Rick tries. To the point where things get apocalyptic. The world get's fucked beyond repair, and while it's shocking to see it go so far the show is still relatively new... you think you know the pattern: Rick will figure things out in the end. Of course, as we all know, instead he just takes Morty and bails. They find a reality where the world is saved, and they happen to die around the same time. There are infinite realities, after all. So, along with an amazing background song, they bury their corpses and return to their "normal" lives, with the last image being Morty's blank and traumatized stare. It's hard to top. **One: 3x07 The Ricklantis Mixup** I literally love every little detail about this episode. I love that despite the title and set up, we never see Atlantis. As for the "Tales from the Citadel" stuff... like the Jerry Daycare and the Interdimensional cable box, this is such a brilliant concept within the context of the universe. We not only get an insight to a purely Rick and Morty world, but we see a decent depiction of real life struggles- political, social, cultural, and the familiar plight of the working class. These are explored through the stories of separate Ricks and Mortys who are making their way in a world that is re-building itself in a lot of ways- but one that has a lot of problems just like any society. Each of these stories have some amazing jokes, but what makes this episode so great for me is the way that it ties in the familiar problems and personal struggle in a way that ends up in a depressing but personal ending for each storyline. Of course, the big plot of the episode is the one that ties them all together, the rise of a Morty to become president of all Ricks and Mortys. And though many are already suspecting it, the reveal that it is Evil Morty and the foreshadowing of his plans now that he has changed everything is possibly the single most breathtaking scene in the show. There was something else, too... oh yeah... That song, tho...

WRITING.TITLE: [Spoilers] Even more evidence that a popular theory about a certain "evil" character is the actual truth.
WRITING.TEXT: Okay, so obviously I'm talking about Evil Morty. And the theory I am refering to is the one that Evil Morty was the original Morty of the Rick that this show is following. This theory is already a popular one, but I saw something the other day that straight up convinced me that this is what is going on. The scene I'm referring to is in bold below, but for context I am first going to go over the clue that I have seen discussed the most. One of the biggest pieces of evidence that I have seen people mention for this theory is from the episode that first features "Evil Morty". When Rick is being shown his memories on screen, there is a shot where he sees a baby Morty in his arms. Now this is seen as evidence based on the fact that Rick has been out of the lives of the C-137 Smith family for 20 years, so he wouldn't have been around to see THIS Morty as a baby. Now this one example alone could just have been oversight, but like I said I did notice another big piece of evidence. **And here it is: As I was re-watching episode 2x05 "Get Schwifty", I noticed something about the scene with Bird Person. Morty is looking at pictures of Rick when he is younger, and he sees one where Rick is holding him as a baby. This scene has an important feel to it, like they were making a point of showing this to us viewers. And how does Morty react? He asks "What's that? Who's that baby?" Now it should seem pretty obvious it's baby Morty to us, but I realized how telling it is that Morty had to ask who that baby was. It is again because Rick wasn't around when he was that age, so seeing that confused him. Of course the question is ignored and the scene continues.** This being added on to the evidence we had before has pretty much convinced me that Evil Morty is THIS Rick's original grandson. I'm going to lay out all the evidence together now, with my take on it, and then go over the implications of what it will mean. So the first scene, in which Rick sees the memory of baby Morty, shows that Rick tears up when he sees the memory. Taking in consideration what we know of Rick as a character, he has not been extremely sentimental in the past. At least I don't think he's the type of person to get emotional looking at old pictures/memories. Plus, he looks truly sad in this scene. I think it makes way more sense if something truly tragic happened with his original Morty, and seeing the memory brought up THAT feeling again. Now, the scene that I mentioned comes in season two. This alone is big in my mind, because they didn't include Evil Morty in this season. The creators have said that they want the show to be episodic in nature, but they do want to include an over-arching story for the viewers that *pay attention*. They gave us Evil Morty in season one, and now a full season later they include this subtle reference to the idea that Rick had been around for a Morty during his early years- this time, however, it seems to do this while specifically alluding to the idea that THIS Morty did not have a Rick in his life at that time. At that point, I don't think there's any way it's just an oversight anymore. It seems the writing for the show has made things pretty clear: * For the C-137 Smith family, Rick has been gone for 20 years. * Morty is confused by the identity of "baby Morty" in the picture with Rick * Rick has memories of Morty as a baby that have a strong emotional resonance within him. I think the implication is pretty clear, and now in season 3 we have a big return of Evil Morty, and very clear foreshadowing that he will be important to "our" Rick and Morty in the future. Another fun little parallel here: In season 3, Evil Morty is asked about his original Rick... and just like when Morty asks Bird Person about the baby in the photo, the question is avoided not just by the person being asked but by the show itself. Now the theory is popular and some people think it will be too predictable. I disagree. It mostly seems predictable because the internet has discussed in in depth like I am now. Also, I think this is the part of the story we are meant to be able to figure out. They want to reward the fans who pay attention, so if we are looking for some deeper meaning to the story this is not meant to be a surprise. I think the reveal of this situation, the way it plays out, and the actually history of it will be the part that may surprise us. I mean not only does the idea of what made this Morty "evil" have potential to be big, but the idea behind his intelligence is also crazy; the whole "a cocky Morty can lead to bad things" quote makes it sound like every Morty has the same potential. Not 100% confirmation but it seems to insinuate that to me. However, there is a deeper implication here that I have not seen much discussion on: if this theory is true, and "Evil Morty" is this Rick's original grandson... does that mean he is not the same Rick who left our Morty's family 20 years ago? Maybe whatever happened to make Evil Morty go bad involved C-137 Rick somehow- maybe even killing him. The situation was so bad that that Morty's Rick had to bail, and maybe came to C-137 Morty not just to try again with a different Morty but also because he felt responsible for the death of C-137. Of course that is purely speculation, but it definitely shows how much there still is we don't know about this "twist".
