WRITING.TITLE: [Spoilers] What makes Pitou an empathetic character
WRITING.TEXT: I came across the question of why people would care about Pitou or in some cases support her character. I liked the question and the way it made me analyze her character, so I wanted to share that analysis. There won't be new information for most of you guys, and this might not be a radically different view from a lot of your own. However the question does get asked, and while I do not set out to change anyone's mind, I very much enjoy having others *understand* the other point of view. Plus, I love reading other peoples' analysis of HxH, so maybe you will just enjoy this for what it is. --- --- The point I want to start with is in relation to the Chimera Ants in general. A huge part of the CA arc is how the human ego impacts these creatures, in both positive in negative ways. For example, it allows for the ants to become self-serving, egotistic, and emotional- but also at times empathetic and even sometimes caring. However, on the other side of this, all the ants are born with several very non-human characteristics. They are loyal to the Queen or King in a way that is biologically ingrained in their animal makeup. Let's take the "humanity" out of the picture. When animals sense danger, especially to their family (including the Queen/King), they will take out that danger. A lion will kill other animals without question to feed its young. The ants have a human side, yes, but all of this is still what they are BORN with. I love the symbolism of Kite saving Gon as a child in relation to this arc... he scolds Gon for entering THEIR territory when they are KNOWN to be dangerous- and this is exactly how Kite "dies" when they approach the nest. They were entering the territory of a dangerous species that would perceive their actions as a threat to what they are protecting and nourishing. The last thing I want to bring up before specifically talking about Pitou is human empathy. Our empathy and morality is not something that happens overnight. We learn over YEARS what "right" and "wrong" is. Even after years of life, human children will still bite, kick, and hit if they are angry. It takes growing through experience and living with others to learn true empathy and compassion for others, and to determine your own moral code. Finally, this brings me to Pitou. When she is introduced, it is very clear she is a villain. Her character design is creepy, her aura is dark, but it is her first actions that put her in the role of a villain. The first things she does are to probe a living person's brain for information and then kill a beloved protagonist. From this point on, it's understandable that many people would just be ready for Gon to kick her ass and hate her. However, she had only been alive for a day at this point. No matter how linguistic, logical, or advanced she was, she had NO time to develop any of her human empathy or feelings. Her actions at that point were very animal. Of course she was going to kill a threat to her King. The change in Meruem's character is a part of HxH that put in display by the CA arc, and we SEE that growth of empathy in him. He starts off listening only to his animal instincts- i.e. eating children. But slowly, through EXPERIENCE and TIME with Komugi, he becomes empathetic. Pitou's development is not a main focal point of any story arc, so it's not as easy to see. But it is there if you look. Meruem's decision to play games and keeping the "champions" alive until he defeated them gave him the opportunity to spend time with a human and relate. Pitou does not have this same opportunity, and for most of the arc she is following her animal side. I think the palace invasion is where the first time the human side begins to affect her. It all starts when she finds the King holding Komugi. It is very much stressed how she can read his emotions before she even sees him, and can feel his emotions through his aura. This seems to affect her a lot, and I think this is where she starts to realize that apart from her insane loyalty, she cares that the King is sad- and that her caring goes beyond loyalty and into the territory of "love". Love is a very human thing. The King, without any threat, asks Pitou to heal Komugi in such desperation, and says that he is counting on her (which feels more like a friend asking for help than a King making a command), and Pitou *cries*. I think that is a huge indicator that something has changed in her. When Gon comes across her healing Komugi, Pitou explains that she is doing it because Komugi is "important to someone who is important to her", and that without her the King will cease to be who he is. Not even an hour before any of this, she had told Pouf that she was okay with killing Komugi if she became a weakness to the king. She is clearly operating in a very different way at this point, and it gives credit to the idea that her witnessing the King in pain triggered her human side to grow. Her interactions with Gon as she heals Komugi are another big factor for her growth, I believe. She sees up close and personal, in a way that drastically affects her, how much pain and anger her actions brought to Gon. While at first, all she could think about on the surface was how to survive while still healing Komugi, I think Gon's pain sinks in for her. To go a bit further, I believe she connects his pain of losing someone to the King's pain over Komugi, which she had JUST felt herself. From this point until her death, she does not show Gon any malice at all. She wants to kill him, but only because she still perceives him as a threat to the King. She takes no pleasure in the idea. We see this again in a big way when she reveals that Kite is dead. She explains the whole thing respectfully to Gon, and she seems to be genuinely sad about what she is saying. She remembers him and what she did, and she tells him she is sorry. NONE of this was necessary, she could have just killed Gon as soon as she found out the "Pouf had Komugi". Instead, she respects him and his pain, as if she understands it. When Gon collapses, his mind literally breaking, the look Pitou has when she watches is very sad. It is clear that when she acts to kill him, it is not as an evil being or with malice. It is her not only doing what the animal loyalty she has requires, but she is also protecting a *friend* in the King (friend may be much, family may be more appropriate). When she is killed, her last thoughts are how she is glad that it is her and not the King dying. I think the bottom line reason that she can be empathetic is this growth in her personality. I think people tend to take more joy in her death than the King because in Meruem's case, his arc is centered around this change. His role is to change and die with love in his heart. Pitou's role is very different, she is there as an antagonist in Gon's storyline... but being created by Togashi, she is still an extremely well written character and that change is THERE. Along with not being a big focal point of the arc, her growth just didn't have as much time and circumstance as Meruem. I think if she had been left alive, we would have continued to see a lot of Growth, and that she had potential to even become moral. I have always seen some tragedy in her death. Of course what she did was horrible, but she had just begun to learn and grow. She was essentially an extremely functional child starting to learn right from wrong, and died extremely loyal to the one she loved. This in essence is what I think makes her empathetic as a character, and it's why I "care" that she dies.

WRITING.TITLE: Does anyone else get slight TMV vibes from this album?
I don't really know what this is.
WRITING.TEXT: I don't know what I want this post to be, I just haven't been able to explain any of this to anyone I know personally. I'm just lost, and I'm not sure where to turn. I was raised in the southern US under unorthodox parenting and schooling, where creativity and individuality were encouraged along with love and compassion. Of course this environment breeds people who think outside the box and in turn question the things around them instead of accept it blindly. As I grew older, I developed a more "artistic" personality. I've been writing since I was a small child. Whether or not I'm any good, it's the only thing I've ever really been able to do or find any "purpose" in. When I hit my rebellious teen years, I found fundamental "issues" in everything- the government, school, society as a whole, all of it was flawed. While there was truth in what I saw, I think I was just realizing that life here would never be what I was raised to believe it could be... and that I was most likely just looking for any excuse to fight back. Inevitably I dropped out of high school and started to experiment with drugs. I had been exposed to weed and some pharmaceuticals in high school (particularly downers like xanax or hydrocodone), but I became very curious about the psychedelic experience. Some of my strongest experiences were a series of dxm trips shared with a friend of mine. It had been a legal and available high, but it also was my first introduction to hallucinogens. Once I began to experiment with LSD and psilocybin, I separated even further from "regular society". At first I abused them, as I had with most drugs before, but over the years I learned to respect them so much more. Despite dropping out of high school, I did actually end up starting college. I had no interest in college prior to this, but I had a friend who ended up going somewhere out of state and amazing and I had to follow. It was an incredible experience, one full of creativity, amazing people, nature (it was a farm college in the mountains, absolutely beautiful) and some of the best psychedelic experiences I've ever had. It was the best year of my life, and I was not only writing more than ever but living with purpose- but of course reality eventually hit. They raised the tuition the following year, and even on top of the loans I qualified for and financial aid my family was already struggling to help with the rest... I was unceremoniously kicked out, with the accounting office not even answering or returning calls to my parents to figure out what could be done. Instead, they just put a letter in my student post box saying to be out by the end of the week. Once I returned home, I turned back to the downers I had relied on in high school. I developed a habit of needing something to bring me down every night, and this led to an addiction to painkillers. Since then I went to school for computer programming, but there was no passion to drive me and I couldn't keep my grades up. That's when I started waiting tables, and I honestly loved it. It was more money than other part time work, and for some reason I'm really good with people. I also enjoyed taking care of people and giving them a good time while they were out, and this was a job where my pay was dictated by how well I did that. I thought that maybe this could lead to a career in the service industry, and now I'm back at community college taking classes for hospitality management. But the lifestyle is starting to wear on me, and working in restaurants has only increased my drug intake. Though I occasionally have some amazing experiences with hallucinogens, my drug use has turned into taking downers and lying in bed. Someone close to me said something the other day that hit pretty close to home- he said that he was reading a book by a survivor of the nazi concentration camps, and it described one factor in everyone who was able to survive: it was purpose. With all of the horror that was happening, the ones who were able to preserver were the ones who could wake up every day with a purpose to keep going. And I feel like this is true in life, after all what's the point in any of this if you don't have a purpose? After twenty five years, I'm facing the fact that the society I live in is built around money and materialism. And I've fallen into it, I tune out every night and dull my mind while watching netflix on my Smart TV. But I grew up without any ties to it, and abandoned a search for a "career". In the past couple of years, I've written less than any other time in my life. The only time I'm not depressed is when I travel, and I would love to see the world. But I don't know how, I have no valuable skills or education to get me into a good position of power, and a considerable amount of debt tying me to this place. If I just left the country, my parents who co-signed my loans would be responsible for that. I don't know what I want from anything, but I'm afraid that I don't have a purpose. The only true calling I have is not something that can sustain me in this society... And I have nothing else to guide me in supporting myself here. And I see what's happening in our country lately- our current president is trying to make it even harder by helping the rich while further hurting students and part time workers. I'm starting to be afraid that I don't have what it takes to survive here. I've lost passion for everything. I don't care enough to work so hard just to come home and get high. I've had some spiritual development in my life, but every time, like clockwork, I eventually sink back into this cycle of medication and tuning out. I just want to see the world. I want to travel around, writing songs and poetry for my own fulfillment. I'm not lazy, I work hard, but the monotony of doing the same thing day after day just to sustain a life without meaning is draining me. I've even considered suicide, but I couldn't do that to my family- I probably wouldn't have nerve to go through with it anyway. And when I hit that point, where the idea of dying sounds like an easy way out, I think- why not just leave? If I can't find meaning in this society to the point where death is an option, why not sacrifice everything to just leave. I could spend the rest of my life sick, poor, and on the streets and die alone, but I could do it while seeing more of this world than I am now. I know this all sounds melodramatic, and it is... I should probably talk to a psychiatrist, I've been told by SO many people I'm depressed and should be on medication. I was on anti-depressants for a month or so, but I hated the entire time. I felt awful every second of it. I know I'm just an entitled kid complaining about "how hard life is", but I think the fact is that I'm just now realizing that I in no way want to be a part of the life we have here. I want change, and I don't know where to go from here. I know change is something you must do for yourself, and I do understand the idea that nobody controls your happiness but you. Am I crazy for feeling incapable of happiness trapped where I am? I know this is just a long post of ranting, and I'm not sure how appropriate it actually is for this sub. I welcome advice if you have it, but most of all if you read this- any of this... thank you. Mostly I just haven't been able to vocalize this to anyone in my life, and I needed an outlet for all of what I've been feeling. Thank you for your time, and I sincerely hope all of you are well.

WRITING.TITLE: [MCU SPOILERS] Finished my third full rewatch of Civil War. Liked it more each time. Here are some thoughts:
WRITING.TEXT: I have to admit, I was ever so slightly disappointed when I saw Captain America: Civil War in theaters. There are a few factors at play for that; for one, I ate too many weed edibles, which made the movie intense but also a little hard to follow at times. Also, I was way beyond hype for the movie, to the point where I was basically expecting it to be an Avengers movie. While it had elements of that, it certainly wasn't one, and wasn't supposed to be. I remember being a little let down by this, and feeling like it peaked at the airport scene while the rest of the movie failed to live up to that part. Don't get me wrong I really enjoyed the movie, it just didn't match my hype. When I watched it again, I had a clearer head and went into it more as a Captain America movie and I enjoyed it a whole lot more. There were so many awesome things about the movie, and after a rewatch I realized it was in my top three. I've recently rewatched the whole MCU, only skipping a couple I had seen very recently- Civil War, for some reason, was one of them. It wasn't that recent that I had seen it, but for some reason it was still really fresh in my head. I just watched it again, and I can honestly say that it is my favorite film of the MCU. After having seen so many of the other movies in order recently, there was just so much to appreciate in this movie... and I'm so much more into Cap's character in the MCU than I was last time, and so this felt like an amazing movie for him. It was the perfect end to his solo-film arc. And it really was his biggest challenge. This time, I loved the whole movie to the point where I wonder if even Infinity War can challenge it (I hope to eat that sentence later, seeing is IW is bigger than anything yet and is also helmed by the Russo brothers). There were so many things I appreciated in this re-watch, and for the sake of simplicity I'll just list a lot of what really stands out to me. Note: As much as I want to rant, everyone and mother has explained why they love some of the stuff in this movie- like the airport scene, spidey/panther's inclusion, how well the debate was done between all the heroes and how natural their opinions felt, and so on. These are all obviously a big part of why this is my favorite MCU film, but not what I want to talk about. * The first scene (after the intro scene) is incredibly well done. It shows how the Avengers go about "normal" business, brings back a familiar face for an antagonist, and sports an amazing sequence of action and "ability-combos" with brilliant choreography. Not unheard of for an MCU movie, but it is impressively well tied with the root conflicts of the film (a person with a vendetta against the Avengers who is willing to put others in danger AND the fact that the Avengers are in a foreign nation implementing their own "justice") and it leads beautifully into the emotional payoff that sets the rest of the movie up: the reveal of Bucky's involvement and the accident that causes the deaths of many innocent lives. So not only does the movie kick off with amazing fast paced action, it jumps right into the heart of the conflict in an emotinally satisfying way. * RDJ tears it up in this movie. His performance of Tony's pain is I think his best of the series. The guilt he feels (his weapons, Ultron, the battles of the Avengers), his separation from Pepper, the accords themselves and the divide of the Avengers, his relationship with Steve and of course the heavy stuff with his parents. This, along with several movies developing who he is now put him in a unique position in these movies. He wasn't a villain, but in this Captain America movie he WAS the antagonist, but he was one who was compelling emotionally and was making a lot of sense- not to mention this is a character built up for a long time that we already have loved. This kind of antagonist is rare in super hero movies. * I really appreciated more this time was how fluidly they took such a big conflict and brought in everyone while keeping it a Captain America storyline- ultimately bringing it back in to him. It all came down to his choice: His country and the Avengers, or doing the right thing by his oldest friend. He sacrificed everything to do what he thought was right. And now the climax of the movie, which I used to think didn't live up to the airport, is now easily one of the best climaxes in a movie for me. Not only is the last fight with Bucky, Cap, and Iron Man intense and impressively shot/executed, but it is charged with so much finality and emotion. RDJ and Evan's performances make this intense on so many levels. We have Cap fighting to protect his friend and Tony is full of grief and anger after learning what really happened to his parents, betrayed by what Rogers kept from him, and despair over how the team had been ripped apart. It's amazing film for Stark, but of course it all comes down to Cap and his final choice- throwing down the shield and leaving the Avengers to do what's right in his mind. It's a great action sequence with a heartbreaking conclusion. The last thing I want to mention is what stood out to me the most during this viewing. Since this movie released, I have heard many times that the film's biggest weakness was the villain, Zemo. Now, he is by far one of my favorites. Yes, the core conflict of this movie were the issues with the Avengers and Zemo was NOT necessary in showing these. However, he is the embodiment of the whole conflict. He is a direct victim of the destruction left behind on the battlefield of the Avengers, just a normal guy who lost everything because of these crazy forces that now exit. But why is he one of my favorites? I find him well acted and written, yes (even if he is a subtle aspect of the movie), but what I've grown to love about him comes down to what he is and what he accomplished. Other than a man connections to follow and a lot of grief, he is very normal. In fact, his the most "normal" villain we have had yet. He has no powers, no top-tier technology, no history of war and strategy (other than what little knowledge he has picked up), and no ties to cosmic or supernatural forces. He's just some guy with a very understandable and emotional reason to hate the Avengers. He's no genius, but he is smart... and that's the thing, he was smart enough to think differently than everyone else who took on the Avengers. He was able to take what was already there and use that to let THEM do the job for him. And THAT is the thing... This normal guy who lost everything is the only villain so far to actually defeat the Avengers. He never took them on in a physical fight, and only interacted with them a couple times, but he actually won. I mean let's look at what he wanted to do. He decided that, instead of fighting the Avengers, he would use their differences and their own fragile relationship with the governments of the world to have them destroy themselves. It required a different perspective to attempt this, but it's not some crazy genius scheme. His determination, however, allowed him to take what he had and use it- and he accomplished what he wanted to do. Let's look at the results: Captain American no longer exists, he is now a fugitive along with Natasha and Sam. They are doing what they can, yes (out of the US if I am not mistaken), but they are certainly no longer Avengers. Rhodes is currently seriously injured and out of commission (for now), Vision and Wanda have a lot to work through now and Wanda especially does not have great public relations, Hawkeye is retired again, Hulk and Thor have been gone, and Tony seems to be working alone to escape a threat he senses to be coming. Everyone else is either alone or a fugitive or both. The Russo brothers have said that they wanted to do Civil War because they wanted the Avengers to be divided and not at all in unity when the ultimate threat comes. For all purposes as of now, that is how they are and the Avengers are no more. They have actually been defeated and stopped for the first time. --- **TL;DR on my biggest point** **Zemo is now one of my favorite villains: he has no powers, abilities or crazy technology... just a compelling past that causes him a lot of grief and pain, with only the Avengers for him to blame. So, as a completely normal guy, he single handedly uses the state of the Avengers and the World to successfully tear them apart and defeat them for the first time.***

WRITING.TITLE: My theory and hope as to how this series continues to an end.
WRITING.TEXT: My theory is based on the few few arcs of Hunter X Hunter. In the very first, the Hunter Exam, the entire series is pretty much set up. What a Hunter is, how the main characters become involved with them and how it relates to the overall story, and especially the main character's motivation throughout the whole thing. The basic plot that is established boils down to Gon's desire to become a Hunter and find his father. But I feel like we can simplify it a bit more; the story is Gon searching (or hunting) for what he doesn't know. I'll touch on this a bit more later, but the point is that the first arc serves to set this story up, and allow it to be the over-stretching plot of Hunter X Hunter. Of course, HxH is known and praised for its ability to explore a wide array of stories, plots, and large arcs throughout its course... and while each has its own conflicts and very distinct tone, they are all connected in some way by the original over-arching plot. However, in the first couple arcs after the exam, there are a few *main* story lines that are almost as important as the central story of the series. **Zoldyk Family** sets up the dynamic of the Zoldyk family, and how important Killua is to them. Especially with later events in the series, their relationship with Killua is very unresolved and will undoubtedly be a big factor later on. **Heaven's Arena** Set up Gon's fierce desire to become stronger, along with training in nen, both of which become a huge driving force for the rest of the series. Hisoka, I believe, is used in this arc as a symbol for where Gon wants to get to in his own strength. This arc also ends by establishing Killua's goal to follow Gon until he finds something *hew wants*, and as he becomes so close to Gon his search begins to tie very deeply into the story's true plot of Gon's search. And in **Yorkshin City**, we really start to tackle Kurpika's personal vendetta with the Phantom Troupe, as well as the nature of the Troupe itself. We get a great arc that focuses on Kurapika's rage and search (again, hunt) for revenge... and while it ends in a satisfactory way it does NOT resolve this story at all. Kurapika still harbors a bitter rage and the Troupe is (as of NOW) still around. The **Greed Island** and **Chimera Ant** arcs are no longer setting up main over-arching story lines, but testing the characters where they are and their drive to go forward. In particular, the **Chimera Ant** arc acts a climax of these characters. Then, we have the **Election arc**, which seems to resolve a lot. Gon finally meets his father and Killua finds something to do (help his sister). This could be the end, and it works well as one in the 2011 anime... but it isn't. I think that this is the midpoint of that overall story, and Gon and Killua's achievements are only milestones in a bigger picture. They are Hunters... they are obviously always going to be on the hunt for something. Like Ging before him, Gon will continue to search for something beyond his reach. And this *hunt* will be the drive of the series... but because it is everlasting it could potentially take the story on forever. However, I do believe that Hunter X Hunter will have a definitive ending (if Togashi finishes it, with all due respect to that mastermind). Curious about that ending, my theory on the remaining arcs of HxH is based on those first couple arcs that set up the sub-main-plots. I call it a mirror theory, because I feel like the remaining half of the series will use its arcs to complete the story that each of those first arcs set up. We'll start with the **Expedition** arc, which in my theory is very separate from the true **Dark Continent** arc. I believe this will resolve the main plot line with the Phantom Troupe and Krupika's hunt for revenge, mirroring **Yorkshin**. It's already revealed that the last eyes of the kurta are on this ship, along with the Troupe themselves (with Hisoka as a wild card). All the pieces are there to wrap up Kurpika's MAIN arc. With everything going on, I believe the ship will turn into an all out bloodbath, and it will resolve Kurapika's main conflicts once and for all. However, I believe the resulting chaos of what will essentially be war on the ship will cause the entire ship to stay at their first stop to deal with the damage and fallout, delaying the true trip to the dark continent. I believe this will be a moderate to long arc, but it will end around this point. Next, I believe there will be a short **Gon-centric** arc. It will mirror **Heaven's Arena**, as Gon will try to regain his ability to use nen, much like he awoke it at first in **Heaven's Arena**. I believe that when he does accomplish this, he will learn that Don Freecs lives on the Dark Continent and has found an insane power there. Curious to find that power, Gon will desire to reach the DC. Then, there will be a **Killua-centric** arc, where his family attempts to hunt him and Alluka down. Killua, being a prodigy, will not only outsmart them but finally convince them to leave him alone. This will resolve all issues with his family... Except Illumi, who will still secretly harbor a grudge. However, the arc ends with Killua wanting to find the dark continent to discover something about "Something's" true power (since she is from there). This will unite Gon and Killua's separate arcs. This is where the real **Dark Continent** arc begins, as all the main characters meet up where the ship is still harbored, and the journey to the DC is back on. This arc will be the longest of the series, and will in a way mirror the **Chimera Ant** arc... except that instead of being the climax for the first half of the story, this will be the climax for the whole thing. I don't have exact predictions of how this arc will go, but here are just a few small theories I have: * Don Freecs will be the strongest character in the series * There will be ancient secrets about nen discovered there, along with the mysterious symbols and characters that enhance and manipulate Nen * Don may be the villain of the arc. Either way, he will be strongly tied to the aforementioned secret knowledge. Gon will be desperate to uncover the secrets. * It will be the biggest struggle any of them have faced by far. It will be really dark but also heavy on the fantasy elements. After the **Dark Continent** arc, there will be ONE last arc for the story. It will essentially be a *resolution* arc. I expect it will wrap up lose ends of the main plots that have been resolved- stuff with the Hunter Association maybe, or if Kurapika is still alive it could show how he is adapting to a post-revenge life. Leorio as prestigious doctor, so on and so forth. I do expect there to be some action, and I think the resolution arc will have three main fights: Killua vs. Illumi, Gons vs. Hisoka, and Ging vs. Parriston. In my more specific theory, I believe Parriston will obtain some insane force from the Dark Continent and use it to fuck with the world- kind of the way he got himself some Chimera Ant nests to use for his own benefit. Ging will try to stop him, and enlist the help of Killua and Gon. By this point, Gon will be strong enough for Hisoka to want to REALLY challenge, and Parriston will hire Illumi/Hisoka to handle the two of them. Those fights will be the end focal point of the final arc, and it will end with Gon deciding what to hunt next- maybe a voyage back to the DC to learn more. Just theories, but I would honestly like it if it all goes this way (assuming it ever finishes). **TL;DR** **The end of the ELECTION arc is the halfway point. There will be five arcs left in the series. This one, the expedition, which will resolve the story of Kurapika and the spiders but delay the DC voyage for a bit. Then, an arc for Gon to get his nen back and learn about Don Freecs and his father's journey to the DC. Third, an arc for Killua finally dealing with his family's hunt for him and Alluka, resolving issues with his family (except Illumi), but deciding to go with Gon to the DC to discover the secrets of "Something's" power.** **This will all lead to the big climax of the entire series, the DARK CONTINENT, in which ancient secrets about nen and the Freecs family will be revealed. It will be the longest and darkest arc, bigger than the climax of the Chimera Ant arc.** **Then there will be one last arc to wrap everything up with character resolutions and the Hunter Association. Maybe a final battle with Gon vs. Hisoka, Killua vs. Illumi, and Ging Vs. Parriston.**

WRITING.TITLE: Toby Flenderson kind of sucks (not a shitpost)
WRITING.TEXT: Okay, maybe that was a little harsh. He's very mild mannered and at times can be likable. There are a lot of factors that lead one to feel sorry for him, such as his divorce and relationship with his daughter, as well as the way Michael treats him. But over all of my rewatches, I've started to get annoyed with him in various circumstances. To start, he kind of sucks at his job. On the surface he's agreeable and tries to help people when he can. However, on a much deeper level, it's obvious he doesn't care about his job. It's not just that he seems to have no passion for his work, because that applies to many others as well. He overall just doesn't take things very seriously, and while in that particular office that makes sense a lot of the time he is human resource- he needs to take things way more seriously. Though Dwight is obviously crazy a lot of the time, it was really unprofessional to not file any of his complaints against Jim... and while the pranks are funny and Dwight had it coming, you have to admit those complaints Dwight made are very valid, and the systematic pranks against him were far from professional. Toby also commonly allows his own emotional biases to affect his decision making in his position in the office. A lot of this has to do with Pam, and the way he handles his feelings for her is possibly my biggest problem with Toby. First of all, his crush on her is a very creepy "from afar" type of thing. He's like a young child who constantly wants attention from the girl he likes and will try to get it but is too scared to say anything. Of course, this attitude prevents him from ever saying anything to Pam and she ends up with Jim. Pam and Jim are perfect for each other and had a long history of chemistry, so things may have ended up this way anyway... but she admitted to thinking Toby was cute, so he may have ended up getting to go out with her if he made a move. It's not that he didn't make a move though... it's how this creepy and pathetic obsession from afar affects his actions AFTER Jim gets Pam. He has no one to blame but himself for not making a move, but he continues to be passive aggressive to Jim for a long, long time. He complains about their relationship (anonymously) before they go public but uses his position to make a big announcement about it, calling them out specifically. No one else even knew anything was going on, Jim and Pam were obviously not acting in extremely unprofessional manner, this was obviously just Toby being petty. This is not the only instance where Toby uses his position of HR to be petty about their relationship. He also refuses to give them a form to disclose their relationship to Dunder Mifflin, saying that it's only for "serious" relationships and insisting they should wait to see what happens. Additionally, when Ryan is being unfair and giving Jim an official "warning" about his work performance (also for ulterior motives), Toby also uses his position in HR to enforce this warning (I'm sure it actually went down on the record as well), citing how much time Jim spends with Pam. It is extremely obvious in this scene that Toby only does this because of his jealousy. On the whole, whenever Toby's feelings for Pam come up in any situation Toby seems to always handle it the wrong way. For example when he puts his hand on her leg in front of everyone. He obviously does this without thinking and the whole scene is very humorous, and I think this makes the viewer overlook how inappropriate this really is. He just grabbed her thigh because they were having a good time, even if it wasn't overtly sexual this is not a mistake that normal people just make. He never had a relationship with her that would make this action appropriate, and he basically chickens out and leaves the country afterwards. He also is willing to go to Pam's art show over his own child's school play, when the show has made clear that he doesn't get to spend much time with her because of the divorce. We also don't see him often talk about missing his daughter. He is seen obviously caring about her in "take your daughter to work day", but the biggest gesture he ever makes is the whole Christmas Present thing... and it kind of seems like he's more interested in upstaging his ex-wife. Overall, he just seems weak and petty... like someone who causes their own problems and then says "why me?" He never really does anything to better his own situation, and tends to run away whenever anything really gets in his face. I don't hate him as a character, and I don't even think he's a "bad guy". I'm just noticing that he can be kind of shitty sometimes. I'm starting to also see how his personality can be kind of annoying. Maybe Michael isn't as off base as he seems sometimes...

WRITING.TITLE: A review of the album Dictator, from me: some random person you don't know or care about.
WRITING.TEXT: **TL;DR and overall rating at the bottom** I would like to start by stating I feel I will try my best not to compare the album to System of a Down: there are certain songs that do have a very "System" feel to them, and I of course will go over this, but these are two different projects. They share the same song-writer, and this album is tied a bit more to System than the previous one was... and I think this is important to note, but will not reflect on my views on the music itself. I feel that if you go into Scars on Broadway expecting System of a Down, you are doing yourself a great disservice. However, I do believe that a comparison to the first album is more than fair game, so let's dive in. Overall, I definitely would have to say that I prefer this album (Dictator). The more I listen to it (and I have listened to it an embarrassingly large number of times now), the more I prefer it. There are a few reasons for this. I think the first thing that jumped out to me is that this album has a much more serious and somber tone to it, while the debut had a more silly and wacky feel. I feel that while I enjoy his songs that are silly and fun, what makes me fall in love with Daron as an artist is when he gives us more than that. Because he is capable of writing music with a lot of serious emotion behind it. This is why I prefer Scars to Serj's solo work (I also find Serj to be very hit and miss with his songs, but that is not the topic for this post). While I do think that Daron's lyrics can be slightly rough at times, I think his melodies and feelings that he puts into them are far more moving than trying to be clever and topical. I can pretty much say that I have enjoyed every song Daron Malakian has written to some extent, he is very consistent in creating music that is melodic and emotionally raw. And that emotion is what shines in Dictator. Especially in songs like Guns are Loaded, Never Forget, and Till the End, I just really "feel" the songs at my core. But even in songs that I feel are at times *slightly* bland and predictable lyrically, such as Angry Guru or We Won't Obey, I honestly don't care about these issues. I just get caught up in the melody and riffs and it moves me. Like much of what Daron has done, the guitar is really amazing in this album. Six years ago when I heard that 30 second sample of Guns are Loaded, I fell in love with the guitar and it did not disappoint in full. While it's one of my least favorite songs on the album, I have grown very fond of the short solo in Angry Guru as well. However, the highlight I have to talk about? Talkin Shit. I think I had heard live versions of the song, and I enjoyed it. However, hearing the studio version the guitar work just blew me away. And while he usually keeps the solos short and sweet, most of this song was taken up by the solo. And I love that. I have to say it's truly hypnotic, and everytime I hear the song I love it more. I hope that in future Scars on Broadway albums that we get more lengthy solos as well. The album is, of course, not perfect. I truly respect that Daron wanted to do this one on his own. I feel like he needed it, too. And he did it very well, but when you compare it to the original Scars on Broadway line up, it can feel a little lacking at times- especially when it comes to drums. But you just can't beat John's ability, to be fair. Still, while he is a damned brilliant song-writer, I think I prefer him working with a full band. That said, it is incredibly impressive that he did everything himself, especially in in such a short span of ten days. He is an immensely talented individual. I also wish the album was longer, though that's hardly a real criticism. I also feel like the covers were an odd way to end the album, because they were some of the weaker songs (although Gie Mou is a beautiful track) overall. I think that they should have been distributed throughout the album. On the other hand, it does speak to my opinion of Daron Malakian as a songwriter that I prefer his original songs so much. So overall, while the first album has a few advantages to it, Dictator on the whole has better songs, riffs that are in my opinion more impressive, and a more serious feel. I kind of think that when he did the first album he didn't take the project as seriously, it was more of a placeholder in between potential System projects. Now, I get the feeling that he is more committed to Scars on Broadway, especially from the interviews I have heard with his own words. I'm very excited to see what he has to offer in the future, and what line-ups he may choose for future albums. **Rating: 8.5** **TL;DR: Despite occasionally "rough" and predictable lyrics, and the lack of the former line-ups amazing drums, Dictator is a great album that I feel has the generally better songs of the two albums. I enjoy Daron Malakian when he takes the tone of his music in a more serious direction, and I can't wait to see what he does next.** **Favorite Songs: Guns are Loaded, Never Forget, Talkin Shit, Fuck N Kill, and Till the End. We Won't Obey has also grown on me a lot, as has Sickening Wars.**

In my opinion, over the course of the MCU there are three villains who have left the biggest impact on the universe:
WRITING.TEXT: Basically, I feel like these are the top three villains in terms of how much their respective "evil actions" have changed the universe that these stories take place in. Number Three: Loki Not only did Loki expose Earth to a lot of danger from outside the galaxy (not only in the Avengers but in the first Thor), he also set in forth his plan to rule that threatened the Earth so much that Nick Fury finally had to assemble the Avengers. In short, he is the first HUGE threat from another world (that we had really seen so far) and is a big part of the reason we have the Avengers in the first place. Number Two: Helmut Zemo At first glimpse, you wouldn't think Zemo would be make the cut in terms of importance. He is just a regular soldier who lost what he cares about and obviously blames the Avengers. He doesn't have any powers, he isn't trying to rule/destroy the world, and he certainly isn't a "universal threat" on the surface. What makes him so important is that his plan is to end the Avengers... and he succeeds. He gets the right resources, information, and timing and creates a serious divide in the team. After he is finished with his actions, the Avengers are divided and reduced, and no longer the "Avengers" at all really. Of course this is huge for the story on Earth... but the division of the Avengers ultimately allows certain other "forces" to truly DECIMATE the flow of life throughout the entire universe, and it could possibly have been prevented if the Avengers were united to stop it. By forces, I obviously mean... Number One: Thanos This one is obvious. His shadow has been cast over the entire MCU since the first Avengers. He has drastically impacted many characters, which is especially seen in the Guardians films. He is the strongest, both physically and in his sheer will. And he is by far the most ambitious, and he gave the Avengers the toughest and most brutal battle they had ever met. His will had affected so much of the universe before he is even introduced: he has wiped out vast numbers on multiple different planets, gained insane intergalactic standing and importance, and has attained devout followers dedicated to seeing his will done. And, like Zemo, his plan is ultimately a success and in Infinity War he gets exactly what he wants. Unfortunately, unlike Zemo, his ambition is not to merely undo the Avengers. Through his own ability, planning, and self sacrifice, he manages to wipe out half of all life in the universe. Even if the Avengers come together and undo this, the pain and impact he has left upon the MCU will always be felt and is more than enough to earn him the title of the most important villain of the MCU. WRITING.TITLE: A lovely drive-through interaction
WRITING.TEXT: I'm new to this sub but I love getting pissed off on everyone's behalf reading these stories! This is my first post here, and this incident was several months ago. It's not the craziest story I've seen here, but I feel like it's appropriate. So at the time I was living in an apartment in the city, and there was a nearby location for a fast-food chain that I typically really enjoy. My roomate and I picked up some food from their drive through a couple times, and the service typically wasn't great. Nothing major, mostly that specific type of "I don't want to be here and don't care about you" attitude that you occasionally see in fast food. And once or twice they would get the order a little wrong. This never really bothered me... I've worked in the service industry for a long time and fast food jobs can really suck on top of that, so I try to make sure I'm polite and understanding in these situations. Plus I honestly really like the food of this particular chain, so it was worth it to come back. However, one night my roommate and I go to pick up some dinner and the line for the drive through is a little long. When we get up to the speaker to order, the guy on the other end is being particularly short and rude. He definitely was trying to rush us, and that alone isn't a big deal. I get it, there's a long line of people. But when my friend orders his meal, the guy taking our order asks "homestlye, spicy or grilled" in regards to the chicken (this is a paraphrase, not specific terminology used by a business)... but I honestly still to this day think this guy was drunk. He was mumbling and VERY hard to understand. We had been struggling to make out what he was saying the whole time, but for some reason this question just jumbled together really badly when he asked, and his words were slurred and incoherent coming from the little speaker. I asked him politely if he could repeat the question, and he did (somewhat angrily)- but we STILL couldn't understand. One more time, I asked "I'm so sorry, I still didn't catch that". He says "hold on". Next thing we know, this huge guy is walking out from the back door by the dumpster and walking to our car. He starts screaming and cussing about how he isn't "playing games" tonight, and he accuses us of messing with him since we had understood everything he said but that one question. He asked it again, this time it was easier to understand since he was literally screaming it into my window. He was crazy rude and and aggressive, and we were honestly just so taken off guard that we just apologized and answered the question we now heard for the fist time. It wasn't until he went back inside that I started to get angry about it. There's no reason EVER to come outside and start screaming at your customers, I don't care how unhappy you are at your job. Plus he really was slurring his words a lot, I feel like he really may have been drunk. I had heard bad things about the service at this restaurant, but I had figured it was just little stuff like what I had experienced before this. I never went back again (which is a shame because it was the only location somewhat close to me) and the next day I did call to let the manager know what had happened. I was able to give her the time of the incident and I think she knew who I was talking about. I told her it had cost my business there, and figured that they should know that they have an employee that would treat the customers that way. I'm not sure how much she cared just by hearing her on the phone, but I'm still glad I said something because in my opinion that's unacceptable.

WRITING.TITLE: Approaching the last season, I'm starting to fully appreciate how impressive the show actually is.
WRITING.TEXT: There is, of course, a large portion of fans out there who believe the show has declined a lot in terms of quality over the years. In a lot of ways I do agree with this- the writing isn't as clever or subtle as it was in the first couple seasons, some sub plots feel either forced or out of place, and the grounded focus on relationships and political intrigue has decreased to make room for the flashier elements of fantasy. This doesn't bother me, though; in fact I still think that Game of Thrones is one of the biggest, best, and most ambitious shows out there. These books were originally considered to be damn near impossible to film, by professionals and by the author himself. There were too many characters and set-pieces, the story was too massive and the battles just get bigger and bigger. However David and Dan did it, and we got impressively faithful adaptations of the first couple of books (with some exceptions of course) that managed to keep a lot of that subtle mystery and intrigue from the early parts of the story. Even when I first started reading the books and hadn't gotten to the later story arcs, one characteristic that I fell in love with was how the overall story pulls a "reverse Lord of the Rings" in regards to magic. Instead of a magical world fading into a new one, we have a world that has already had its magic fade but is starting to return again many years later. As a result, we have a series that starts off focusing on characters, politics and drama but with the fantasy elements becoming more and more prevalent as the story goes on. I loved the things that make the story unique in the fantasy genre, but I was still very excited to see the mystical side of things to really start affecting the established characters and stories. In a way I'm fortunate that this aspect of ASOIAF appealed to me. I can easily see how someone who was mostly invested in the more grounded stories in the first couple books may be turned off a bit by the show where it is now. It has shifted from a political drama to an all out fantasy epic, and the writing has gotten much more simple on top of that. However, that was always the story we were being told, we just didn't have the *whole* story yet. Even in the books, you can see that the unexplained and "magic" plot points are becoming more important as the series grows longer. The show is just getting there faster, and that's something that they have to do. They know the basic endgame of the series, and they understand what I think is most important: they captured the aspects of the early story that they needed to in order to make the characters and their growth the focus, and threw those characters into the heat of the magic and chaos for the stories climax. For the sake of pacing and keeping the show fresh, they had to make sure that the show didn't run too long, and as a result they had to simplify the story in a timely fashion. Even with the most skilled writers in existence, to do this with a story this big is going to mean that you can't keep writing things in a way that is consistently growing in its complexity. While David and Dan have certainly done one or two things differently than I might have, I still think that they have given us a perfect adaptation for a book series like this. It's surprisingly faithful to the books that are out, and it's reaching a pretty satisfying conclusion (at least for people like me who were always waiting for the fantasy climaxes) without having a source to adapt for it. Thinking of all the hundreds of plots and threads that weave through this series (not to mention the insane amount of fully realized characters), it's honestly amazing to me how few of them disappointed me at all. I think some of the "issues" in the later seasons wouldn't be as easy to spot if the first three seasons or so weren't so damn near flawless. Every show has flaws, and Game of Thrones has less than most- at least in my opinion. Plus the highlights soar so high. We have an awesome visual version of ASOIAF, and I think that as long as we get a satisfying end in season 8 that we should be very proud of what we have been given. So basically this is an unapologetic circlejerk appreciation post for how great David and Dan have done with Game of Thrones. Sure, I've wondered what the hell they were thinking at points in the past few years, but overall they've done a great job bringing this journey to the world of television and as a result of given us one of the biggest, most impacting, and arguably best series of all time.

WRITING.TITLE: My interpretation of the theme of this series.
WRITING.TEXT: I grew up reading A Series of Unfortunate Events, and I fondly remember the excitement I felt as each of the last few books was released. I was young then, so the details from the books has faded a bit, but the enjoyment I got from them is still lodged in my memory. Even thinking about the audio books narrated by Tim Curry gives me a ton of nostalgia. Having felt that the movie was not a satisfactory adaptation, I was cautiously optimistic when the Netflix series was announced. At the very least, I would finally get an adaptation of all my favorite books that had come later in the series, and having read the series so long ago I was hoping to relive the journey that was somewhat hazy to me at the time. And despite tiny nitpicks the series was great and exactly what I had hoped for... and at long last I have seen the end of the series on film and it was amazing. Not just because of how much I enjoyed the ending (which I did), but also because it made me realize so much about what makes this series so amazing. Enough to have convinced me that this was the best children's series I have ever witnessed. There are many reasons I feel this way: not only is it a finely crafted narrative with compelling characters and intrigue, but it also expertly adds elements you would not expect to find in a children's book. The most notable of these elements, to me, are the use of absurd-ism and satire in the story. This is what writing a story for young readers is for: not just to provide an entertaining story for them, but to introduce them to the wider world of literature and themes. Which leads me to what I interpret the central theme of A Series of Unfortunate Events to be... the darkness of growing up. Reading the series as a child I was unable to pick up on this, but having finished the series on Netflix as an adult it is absolutely what I took away from this story. Childhood is often looked upon fondly as a time of purity, innocence, and fun. In turn, as most adults would agree, growing up very much involves losing this innocence and fun as you are exposed to the more serious elements of life. In the series, this is represented by Mr. Poe telling the Baudelaire children that their parents have unexpectedly died in a fire. Most of the adults in the series have a certain ignorance and quirky personality that comes across as borderline absurdist writing, and I believe this is illustrating that all of these "grown ups" have lost that naivety and purity that the Baudelaires carry throughout the story. Even the more the quicker pace of their dialogue represents that they are now "in a hurry" and don't have time to think the same way that they used to. Most of them are so wrapped up in their own interests and motives that they either actively take advantage of the children or are too self involved to help them in any way. Even the adults who do help the Baudelaires and seem to share their moral values have that same quirky personality, and as the series goes on we realize that these adults have a much more complicated sense of morality and a wide history of actions that are not always entirely "good" or "bad". I view the story as a metaphor, where Violet, Klaus, and Sony having to navigate a suddenly confusing and dark world is a mirror for a young person losing the shelter of their childhood as they discover that the world is actually full of danger, strange people and sometimes "unhappy endings". Throughout the series the Baudelaires mention how their parents "did not prepare them" for how complicated their world really was. There are other little things I have noticed in the stories as well, such as how the world seeming so small may represent that as an adult the world isn't as vast and endless as we once thought (hence the phrase "small world"). There are also several encounters with adults in this world that remind me of encounters in the book "The Little Prince", which has very similar themes as those who are familiar with it know. The end of the story is really where all of this is summed up. The island to me represents that purity of youth itself. It's far removed from the dark problems of the world, the residents are "sheltered" from that craziness, and it represents where the entire story begins in many ways. The Baudelaire parents initially wanted to raise the children there, separate from the harsh world. They went back to the mainland because the inevitably realized that children cannot be sheltered forever. It seems fitting for the end of a story about "growing up" for the children to return to that island, and finally make the choice to leave it (their childhood) themselves. When they do go there, they learn many secrets they have been "sheltered" from this whole time, they realize that the "evil man" chasing them the entire time was just as complicated and layered as the ones who were helping the children. And finally they help bring new life into the world, and having to realize the same thing about that child that their parents had realized about them: no one can be protected forever. These lessons and their decision to leave the island is them finally growing up, and the "adventures" the TV series hints at during the ending is basically the Baudelaires leading their adult lives. For some reason the way all of this was portrayed was very beautiful for me, and the story overall serves as a great satire on adulthood on par with "The Little Prince" (and seriously, to the few out there who may not be familiar it is an amazing and brilliant children's book that is very short). This is also just my takeaway, of course, and I am not the one who wrote these stories. My interpretation may not be the correct one, but it works and it's how I felt. For a story to leave me thinking about its themes in this way is something to be applauded. This is a great way for young people of the world to be introduced to the ideas of adventure, literature, and what this journey in life is like. And for a collection of stories about becoming adults to be called "A Series of Unfortunate Events" is both hilarious and satirically brilliant. **TL;DR I believe that the story of the Baudelaire children is a metaphor for growing up from childhood into adulthood, that it is a brilliant children's satire and that the "series of unfortunate events" is the trials and tribulations of getting older and leaving your youth behind.**

To start off as an incredibly annoying kiss-ass with severe anger management issues and grow him into a kind and well-meaning boss with a meaningful relationship is a hard thing to pull off, but the show did it. Then he just turns into a pathetic and shallow caricature of his original impression, and not only does it not make sense it just undoes a lot of what made his character compelling for me. The Office is my favorite sit-com because of its incredibly high caliber writing, and despite what other people may say I truly think it stays at that quality even after Michael leaves. I love seasons eight and nine, they both have some of my favorite scenes, and I think the show's ending is incredibly well written. Andy's character arc in the last season or so of the show is the only time I think the writing is ever bad, but that just makes it stand out more to me in an otherwise perfect show. What do you guys think? I know I've seen a ton of people on this sub that don't like how his character ended up, but do you think it's as bad as I do? Or am I just overreacting? WRITING.TITLE: How much time will Endgame spend on the events after the final climax/battle?
WRITING.TEXT: **There is a tl;dr/main point below the bullets.** Obviously Endgame has an epic-sized amount of stuff to accomplish- not the least of which being how the heroes will deal with Thanos, the infinity stones, avenging the ones they've lost and pretty much fixing existence. But Endgame is also meant to be the big final act of the original Avengers and their interwoven stories. The movie not only has to settle this big final conflict, but it has to serve as an ending for a few characters AND as a set up for a ton of others. Examples being: * **Captain America:** Does he die? If so, why does it happen and how does it impact the others going forward? If not, what is a satisfying conclusion to the story of a man who was taken away from his life and now lives in a strange future where his only purpose in life is to fight/save others? * **Iron Man:** Does **he** die? If so, why does it happen and how does it impact the others going forward? If not, does he have a kid? Does he settle down and have a family, or does he continue to be an Avenger? Or, does he settle down for the most part, only suiting up in the most dire of circumstances? What will be the endpoint for his character growth that we've seen for so many movies? * **Thor:** Is he satisfied with how things resolve in Endgame? Since the Asgardians were actually taken down to half by Thanos' actual force and not the snap, are they brought back at all through time travel? Does he find a new home for his people? Does he stick with Asgard and fulfill his role as King or will he have unfinished business somewhere in the universe? * **Banner/Hulk:** How will the relationship develop? This can go so many different ways, including the "Professor Hulk" scenario, but either way we will need some conclusive understanding of how this was resolved at the end of this film. And whichever way it goes, will it mean he stays on the team as an Avenger, or will he take his journey elsewhere? Does anything happen with Nat or has that storyline been ditched? * **Black Widow:** She may not have as clear-cut of an overall arc as some other Avengers, and I feel like we'll definitely be seeing her again in a few movies to come, but there still needs to be a good resting place for her character in this film. How does the end of this film affect her? I have a feeling she'll continue to be an Avenger, but is there a chance she ends up doing more stuff with SHIELD? They seemed to briefly acknowledge her romance with Bruce in Infinity War, so that may at least need to be addressed one last time (though there's a good chance they just ditched that arc because of audience feedback). * **Hawkeye:** Seeing as they were probably snapped away, does he get his family back, and if so what is their life going to be like? I'm less confident about him returning for future films than Black Widow, but I think he's also more likely to be back than someone like say Captain America. Either way, it seems like he's been trying to retire for a bit. Once the Thanos situation is resolved, will he finally retire for good? There's a lot of potential closure we could for his story. * **"New Avengers":** And of course, there are so many characters going forward that could really use a conclusion in this film so that we see what direction they'll be going in. Will **Black Panther** aid the Avengers moving forward, or will he mostly stay in Wakanda? Likewise, what will the role of **Doctor Strange** be? I assume he will remain Sorcerer Supreme, but will he become an Avenger also? Similarly, **Spider-Man** might need the most of a "transitional conclusion"; he was named an Avenger in Infinity War, will that stick? He seems to still have a "friendly neighborhood" thing going on in the Far from Home trailers, but will he be an honorary Avenger at least? If Stark is alive, what will their relationship look like going forward, and if not, how will it impact him? It's been hinted at that he will be a big part of the MCU post Endgame, and that it is appropriate for his next film to be the first in Phase Four, so I feel like his stuff will need to be wrapped up a bit. On top of that we have **Captain Marvel**, who was just introduced. Will she be easier to contact now, or will she just stay on Earth a bit? Does Endgame change her character arc up, or when we see her again after will it just be more of a continuation from her Origin film? Not to mention that there are TONS of other characters with story arcs: **Ant-Man** and his family, **Vision** and **Scarlet Witch** and their relationship, all of the **Guardians** and how their group will go on (and if any of them still don't make it), and STILL more characters in need of closure. #8203; **MY MAIN POINT:** So after Thanos and the Infinity Stone story is resolved, and everything is (presumably) somewhat returned to normal, there is still a lot of closure needed for a lot of characters; how much of the movie do you think will be devoted to wrapping things up? Honestly, I'm hoping for something like "Return of the King", maybe somewhere in between the standard and extended cuts. I would be totally okay with spending 30 or so minutes AFTER the main action just to see where everyone's at and how things will be going forward. Any thoughts?

WRITING.TITLE: The Walking Dead appreciation:
WRITING.TEXT: The idea that The Walking Dead is terrible now (or has been for years up until season nine) is not rare, especially on reddit and other internet forums. I would never claim that the opinion of others is "wrong", especially one shared between so many people- there's obviously something credible to make so many feel that way. I have to say, though, I just don't see it. I don't find it hard to understand that people would call out problems with the writing and some of the choices made by the showrunners... there is definitely plenty of flaws there to warrant it. I also totally get why many people just don't like it- certain flaws ruin the enjoyment for certain people more than others, and apart from that the show has changed drastically in many ways... it makes total sense that people would be turned off by so much change or by flaws that hinder their enjoyment. I just sincerely can't understand why *so many people* truly **hate** the show to the level that I've seen- or rather I can't personally see why it seems to have become "common knowledge" that the show is just objectively bad overall. I know that the reason I can't wrap my head around it is simply because I feel so differently about the show, and I 100% acknowledge that I'm not some hyper-intelligent expert in television and that it's possible my personal bar for quality for this particular type of show might just be lower than others. It may just be that, and I say this honestly with no sarcasm at all, some viewers just might be smarter than I am, at least in terms of being able to see what makes good writing and television. That said, I'm an amateur writer myself and have enjoyed both creating and consuming stories for decades- literally as long as I can remember. No matter how perceptive I am to "objective quality", I take this stuff seriously. When I get sucked into a work of fiction, I go all in. That includes nit-picking and judging the story on my own standards. The point here being: yes, some seasons have had flaws in pacing, some with writing (be it for the integrity of the story or just logic). Some seasons have leaned a bit too heavily on tricks and "shocking gimmicks", or have just had more general problems with structure or directorial choices. In fact, a good few of the seasons have at least had some instances of all of these issues at some point. But overall, I think the story has had a lot more good going for it than bad, no matter which season you focus on. Throughout the entire run, the show has been consistent in providing: * Complex themes of morality * A ton of interesting and compelling characters * A dangerous world that is both totally different yet in many ways a dark mirror of our own * Attention to the basic necessities of surviving in a zombie outbreak, both obvious and less so. By showing so much time passing from the outbreak to the reforming of many civilizations, it has become the quintessential zombie piece for me just in the sense that you get a real feel for the "full experience" of this disaster, both short term and long term. * A real intensity throughout all of the show's conflicts. There is very little in the way of plot armor, and the from early on TWD has shown that it is willing to do very dark things to the characters. It's easy to randomly kill characters off for shock value, but what is impressive to me is how well the show uses these stakes to create real tension when there is conflict. Sure, there are moments where you can assume that the characters will most likely work everything out, but the entire show is filled with real danger for its characters, and for the most part it really makes you fear for their well-being. Especially in the later half of the show, there is a shockingly low amount of characters that you don't have to worry about dying, because you know the showrunners can't/won't kill them off. Even the rare occasion where you just KNOW an actor isn't going to be booted off, that could easily be subject to change later on in the show's run. * A story of survivors that, while not always the most clever plot around, does invest you into knowing what happens to the characters you are following. * Last but definitely not least, amazing performances by some great actors in the show. All of these points have been consistent in my opinion, from season one all the way through season nine. I know I'm fanboying a bit, but I really think the show has been very impressive overall. The majority can call the show garbage, they have every right to call it like they see it. I love the show as a whole, though, and after nine years of consistently being a story that I enjoy like this I think The Walking Dead has MORE than earned my appreciation.
