(obviously /s) And there are all kinds of things that we all know to be true- D amp;D are arrogant, last seasons are rushed to move on to new projects, ect. But in general, I was prepared for it to be a little rushed, and I could handle the problems with logic (everything with Euron) or just genral sloppiness (coffee cups left in scenes). However, because they rushed the show, I think D amp;D made one specific decision that single handed-ly took the show from "flawed but still acceptable" to the show that has a million people signing a petition to remake the last season. For the record, at their best I think D amp;D are mediocre writers. I think the main reason for this is that they are more concerned with what they themselves and their viewers think about the story rather than the story itself. They admitted that the Red Wedding was the reason they wanted to do the show, and up until that point they kept saying "just get to the RW". They just wanted to see that twist on screen, and see peoples' reactions. Then look at all their inside the episodes, and what really confirms this is they way they talk about all the decisions that *they themselves* made. For example, Lyanna Mormont's death. When they talk about the scene, they don't talk about it's importance to the battle or her character arc. They talk about using the actor, and they talk about how they "thought it would be cool to have her death scene play out this way" (not word for word but this is almost exactly what they said). And if you look into it even just a little bit, they have tons of similar quotes out there about how they do things either because they thought it would be cool or because the actor was good... NOT BECAUSE OF WHAT THE STORY NEEDS. Stoneheart being another big example- they didn't go with a huge (and awesome) plot from the books that even GRRM said was crucial because- yep, because they thought it was beneath the actor. So, for this reason they are definitely not great writers... but mediocre writing is better than NOT writing. Let me explain. So we all know that GRRM outlined the ending for them, and that this took a few days. We know that he has said that he knew where characters were going, but that their journeys and the details weren't there yet because he creates them as he goes along. We also know from both GRRM and D amp;D that the destination for both the show and the books are the same, just with different paths getting there. So here's the major problem: **Instead of creating their own path to GRRM's ending, they just filmed it happening.** This makes so much sense in context with how the show has gone. Seasons four and especially five were when they started having to create their own plot to finish adapting the books but get ready to end it, and this is where we start seeing the flaws really creep into the writing. Now we get to season six... and we know that GRRM has at least SOME of TWOW written, and probably has a lot more insight into what is going to happen in that book than ADOS since he is currently working on it. That's why I think season six had so much good stuff in it even if it isn't as strong of a season as 1-4. They pretty much got to make a season out of all the payoffs in TWOW that they had details about. Season six is probably all of the "journey" that GRRM was able to tell them, other than straight up endings. So while season five was when the show caught up to the books, season six was when D amp;D caught up to GRRM in terms of where he actually is in crafting the story, if that makes sense. So after season six, all they had was the endings that GRRM had told them about. This explains why they only wanted 13 episodes after that and shortened both seasons (even though HBO would give them an even bigger budget to do full seasons). Because they wouldn't be bothered too create their own paths for the characters to take to get to these final conclusions. They just took a few episodes in season seven to bring the characters together, then in season eight they just showed these moments happening. After detailing the plot points that affected season six, GRRM probably said something like: "*After the army of the dead is finally defeated, Dany eventually succombs to Targaryen madness and almost fully destroys kings landing in order to take it, and she has to be killed. Jaime ends up dying with Cersei, and Jon has to eventually face who he is and decide that it isn't what he wants.*" Obviously, there is so much more room for these plots to grow, and a severe NEED of development in order for the story to reach these points and have it make sense. But, like I said, instead of creating their own path, D amp;D just put the characters together and filmed the ending. **TL;DR- GRRM and D amp;D have said that the show and the books have the same destination with different paths getting there, and GRRM creates story as he goes, so he doesn't fully know the path to his destination yet. D amp;D should have come up with their own destination to that ending, even if they aren't the best writers. Instead, they used the meaty bits of TWOW's content to make season six, and made two rushed shortened seasons- one just to bring the characters in one place, and the second season just to film the ending without creating a sensible path to get there. This is why no character's end point feels real or makes sense- D amp;D think so highly of themselves that just having GRRM's ending will make their "brilliant" show good, but they've really just let us all down big time.**

WRITING.TITLE: The contradiction: why I am okay with this episode and even enjoyed it while still being disappointed with the last season(s) and still hating D amp;D.
WRITING.TEXT: I made a post just a couple hours ago talking about how D amp;D ruined the show- it really boiled down to the show not only being rushed, but the fact that instead of making their own path to GRRM's ending D amp;D just made the ending happen with no development to set it up (which results in the nonsense that we've seen so much of). I still stand by that post and my thoughts on that subject 100%, and overall season 8 has been a slopfest... and that's a really generous term for it. However, all of that said: I started having issues with GOT in season four, with the mission to avenge Commander Mormont (mostly because it felt way too focused on action for such a story driven show), the whole fiasco with Yara being chased of by shirtless Ramsay and some dogs, and the exclusion of Lady Stoneheart. Over the ups and downs of the show since then, at times I felt like I was only invested because I wanted SOME glimpse of the ending- and I got that tonight. So that alone is something that I have wanted, and I'm happy I got it. As for the ending itself... I liked it. I feel like this will be an unpopular opinion, but it's the truth. Reading the leaks and having seen the last couple of episodes, I was sure I would hate it. Seeing it play out felt much more right to me though (yes, even "King Bran"). Sure, the episode was a bit choppy here and there... wouldn't expect any less after this season. But I actually thought the characters had good endings to their arcs- particularly Tyrion, Jon, and the Starks. Seeing this ending, I am now MORE than confident I will like the one Martin provides if he ever gets to it. I not only know he can do it better, and without the kind of silly endings for some of the minor characters (fuck everything to do with Bronn this season), but when he writes it the journey to that ending will be thrilling and it will make fucking sense. Character development will be an actual thing, and it won't just be a big twist ending for no reason. Also, on top of all that, there is still SOOOOO much that this version of the ending doesn't spoil. The actual long night and war for dawn, more information behind the others, Euron's significance, the children of the forest/Bloodraven, Lady fucking Stoneheart... and, most importantly, the final season's biggest flaw may actually be a blessing in disguise. Seeing Dany go full crazy Targ may be the ultimate payoff, but I honestly think her decent into that madness would be much more interesting to watch. And since the show didn't really give us that AT ALL, we can actually still go into Dany's story a little blind. I really look forward to seeing how GRRM develops her now. The same with Jaime and other characters who's ending doesn't make sense... I'm really excited to see how GRRM does it. Sure, it's possible that his transition won't be anymore believable, but with his track record of focusing on inner thoughts of characters' and their development (even to where it is almost a fault to some people in the two most recent books), I just don't buy it- I think he has some crazy roller coaster character arcs in store for us. From the beginning, I've been okay with mad queen Dany (it was honestly a theory I believed very likely for a while after reading ADWD), and I think I'm even okay with Jaime going back to Cersei... as long as it makes sense for thee story. I think GRRM will do that. Still, I'm not trying to give D amp;D a break. I hate what they did to these last two seasons, and I truly believe they just got lazy and wanted to move on to Star Wars. I also think they are not good writers overall, and even worse people. I really, really, really don't like them personally, and I wish we got the last seasons that we deserved for this story. Still, like I said, I'm okay with this ending. I've loved this story for so long, and it's meant so much to me. And after so much disappointment, I was able to let it go just a little- long enough to see this story end, and I'm glad I was able to do that. It wasn't the best experience I could ask for in ending a story I've loved this much, but it meant more to me than I thought it would. I think it's possible that I'll get the fully meaningful experience I wanted from the books now, though, and I hope we get there.

WRITING.TITLE: Don't ever rely on the Money Network card that employers often give you.
WRITING.TEXT: I originally posted this on r/talesfromretail but I also have served a lot in the past and know that a lot of restaurants provide this same card. This might be common knowledge to a lot of you, but I had to figure things out in a not-so-fun way, so if my advice can help or persuade anyone to use a real bank or even just get paper checks, then awesome. So I work in a used book store (we sell a lot of other things as well), and I was given a Money Network visa card that says "bank of america" for all my payment because I don't have a bank account. I don't like banks personally, and I don't like to keep up with checking fees and whether or not I'm meeting the criteria to avoid them. Also, this card gave me my paychecks the night before payday at 9:30 EVERYTIME, which was earlier than anyone else got their pay with a bank. So I was content. However... fast forward to a couple weeks ago. Pay day arrives, I withdraw some cash and buy something at my store (not a huge purchase, about $20). I then head to the grocery store. As I walk into the store, I decide to check my account to get an exact number of how much money I have left (even though I had a rough idea in my head. I knew I had a little over $200 after taking out a good bit of cash... but when I look at my account balance, it says $10.95. Of course, I'm very angry and confused, and I look at my account details. Apparently, a $200 purchase was made at Sephora in Raleigh NC (far away from where I actually live). Obviously someone was able to use my card information, so I call the number on the money network card. Here's where the bullshit begins. The transaction was still pending, so they told me basically to call them back when it was no longer pending. They offered to put a hold on my card, I told them to wait (so I could use that last $10 since I was already so low on cash). I hang up, use my cash for my groceries (most of which was supposed to be for rent), and try to use that last $10. Apparently, they put the hold on my account after I told them not to. I was pissed, but figured it may have just been policy when someone told them their card was stolen (they should have made it clearer though). I call back, and tell them that I want to get a replacement card sent to me. After answering a bunch of their questions (I had to do this everytime, they make it take almost ten minutes just to talk to someone), they confirmed my address and told me a new card was on the way. The next day, the purchase was no longer pending. I call them back and ask how to get my money back. They tell me that they have to send me a form in the mail, I have to fill it out and mail it back (there is no electronic way to do this, apparently), and then they can START to dispute the claim. They told me the process to get my money back, IF I get my money back, will take 60-90 days. So basically I'm just fucked. So I'm already getting screwed over, but I try to move on. My parents help me out with $ as much as they can, and I get through the next couple of weeks. I check the mail every day, but I have gotten no form in the mail, and definitely no replacement card. So, two full weeks later, here we are- I get paid at 9:30 tonight, and after getting fucked over last week I NEED my money this time. I check the mail today and... of courses, no card. So I call them to ask for an update. Guess fucking what. They have no record of sending a card, and try to tell me I never asked for one. Imagine my frustration of waiting all this time, and having to jump through all their hoops to talk to their outsourced customer service from another country just to find out that they never did what they said they were going to do, and that I'm now fucked out of my money. They tell me I can use "money network checks" (which I've never heard of and certainly don't have). Since I don't have those, I talk with a "supervisor" who says that when I get paid they can do a one time lift of the hold on my card so I can withdraw my money from the atm. After my experience so far, I'm just hoping it's going to go down the way they said. **So, to sum up: Someone was able to spend my card IN STORE several states away without having it while I have to jump through every security loop imaginable just to get information about it. They put a hold on my card, claimed to send a new one but never did, and due to their process I'll either get my money back in a couple of months or never. All the while dealing with the most incompetent customer service I have ever had the displeasure of speaking to.** **I may not like dealing with physical banks, but it's MUCH better than this bullshit. I'll be setting up an account with one for my next direct deposit, and I'm going to tell everyone I can how shitty this service is and advise anyone I can against it. Fuck Money Network Visa Cards and FUCK "metabank" or whatever they actually are. I'm SOO mad right now.**

WRITING.TITLE: I've gone back and forth a lot on which seasons I like more or less, but since the show has come to an end (and had time to deal with disappointments and frustrations), looking at the show as a whole I'm pretty confident in how I feel.
WRITING.TEXT: When the show was good, it was SOMETHING ELSE kind of good... and I think my ranking of the seasons reflects that. My pick for first place is actually a three way tie. But here's about where I have the seasons ranked. **Sixth Place: Season 8-** Probably not a shock. It's the most flawed, rushed, sloppy, and overall weakest season of the lot in just about every way you can judge them, and it stings all the more because it's the actual ending. **Fifth Place: Season 7-** Even though I like some other seasons more than others, I don't think it's hard to see that in terms of writing and objective quality seasons 7-8 are a good step down from seasons 1-6. Other than s8, s7 has more plot-holes and lazy writing than any other season, and is also the beginning of the shows inexplicable "race to the finish line" where everything just starts getting very rushed. **Fourth Place: Season 5-** Even when it came out I thought people were a little too hard on this season. It had some flaws and deserved criticism, but it still felt like "Game of Thrones" and had some amazing moments. I was still loving the story. That said it didn't have as much excitement packed in as the season before it, and while I believe s4 is where the writing first showed signs of slipping s5 was the first real step down. It was where they caught up with GRRM and had to prepare the show for where "they wanted it to go". **Third Place: Season 2-** Even when it first came out, I feel like s2 wasn't quite as good as s1. It was better paced, the characters and tone felt more assured, and it had some amazing stuff... but the events just didn't feel as "monumental" or important as they did in the first season, and it almost just felt like a bridge from the begging in s1 and the meat of the show in s3. There are some great, GREAT stuff in this season, and like the other great seasons the last two episodes are amazing, but I just don't feel that the story it told beats the one from s1 (or s3 for that matter). **Second Place: Season 1-** It can be an awkward start for some, I've noticed. While there are lots of memorable stuff in the first episode, the show is definitely pretty slow in the start so it can set up such a massive story. Other than the initial shocks and twists that draw you in (i.e. Bran falling) it takes a few episodes to get going. The set-up vibe persists throughout the whole season, making it one of the slower ones, and it also has the daunting cast of establishing so many characters. However, other than having to get used to its own tone, characters, and writing, it's very well done and compelling. Still one of my favorite seasons to re-watch, and the last two episodes are among the show's best. **First Place: Seasons 3, 4, and 6-** So hear me out on this one. This decision was based on a mix of objective opinion and critique on these seasons AND my own personal enjoyment. I think if I were going only by my opinion on objective quality in terms of writing especially, s3 would win. It's got all the subtle writing that made us fall in love with the show and some of the best shocks and twists. All and all it was not only an exciting season but it was when the show REALLY started getting good. Moving on, while s4 arguably had more high points, I've also pointed out that it is where I feel that the show's writing starts to get a bit sloppy and we see D amp;D fall into some of their shortcomings. Their love of shock led to the start of a different tone, and the Cersei/Jaime rape scene was a huge mistake. Then there were also show plots that I didn't like (Greyjoy rescue and Craster's home set-piece). But it cannot be denied so many of the best moments are crammed in this season, and overall the story it tells is one of the best (though it suffers compared to the corresponding arcs in the books). As for s6, it kind of continues a long this pattern. Like s4, it has some sloppy writing but some amazing stuff as well. However, I think what makes it hard for me to compare the two seasons is that while s6 has lower lows, it also has much higher highs imo. The Arya plot was probably the most poorly written plot of the show so far, and there were some other issues with writing- including a lot less subtlety than seasons past. However, if I were to pick my three favorite moments of the show (or even five), they might all come from this season. And while there are issues with the writing throughout the season, I don't agree with the idea I've seen that the season is boring until the last two episodes. Home, Oathbreaker, Book of the Stranger, and The Door, were all GREAT episodes, and I enjoyed the next couple episodes before "No One" as well. But for me, even though Joff's wedding, Tyrion's trial, Oberyn's fight, The battle at the wall, and Tyrion killing Shae and Tywin (other stuff too) are all incredible... they don't beat Dany killing the khals, Hold the Door, Battle of the Bastards, Cersei blowing the sept, Arya killing Walder, R+L=J reveal/KITN, and Dany sailing west (also along with tons of other stuff) for me. The writing quality of s3 along with the brilliant moments in s4 and s6 (along with it being hard to compare 4 and 6 for me) pretty much make them tied for my favorite. Like I said when GOT is at it's best it's something else, and while I would include s1 and s2 in that statement I stil fill like these three seasons are the epitome of what I'm talking about. I know that the flaws of s6 give it some well earned criticism, but I still defend it (and s5 for that matter) as part of the "good days" of GOT. While D amp;D's writing certainly began to get lazier much earlier on, I don't think the show was really sunk by it until s7 and s8. Looking back, those are the seasons that I think the show doesn't even feel the same anymore, and s1-6 are still great in my book and at least belong together. These are just my opinions, and now that the show's over and I've had time to really form them I just felt like writing them out and sharing them. Feel free to add your thoughts and your own views on how the seasons rank, if you feel like it.

WRITING.TITLE: What are your top "less obvious" episodes? (Spoilers for entire show)
WRITING.TEXT: Pretty simple, but let me clarify. There are some HUGE fucking episodes in this show. There are tons of popular favorites, like 35/36 (Gon VS. Hisoka) and 47(Kurapika VS. Uvo), 85 (Pitou VS.((ish)) Kite) and many other. On top of those big episodes, there are the "legends"... the big episodes that you would most like find at least one or two of in the top five of MOST fans... I'm of course talking about episodes like 116, 125/126, 131, and 135. There is so much depth, emotion, and or even just climactic tension packed into these episodes that it's easy to see why fans might consider them their favorites. So forget about all of those episodes. HxH is also full of small emotional beats, beautiful moments of character, and brilliant strokes of writing. So apart from the episodes already mentioned in this post, or ones that you just see people talk about a lot, what episodes do you love so much that you would put in THIS top five (some people may appreciate these episodes more, and in that case this may just be your actual top five). Even if it means I'm as basic as you can get for a HxH fan, I have to admit my top 5 is probably entirely composed of the "big" episodes mentioned above; but there are SO many less "climactic" ones that I love, and so here are my top five: Five - Episode 007: I just absolutely loved the way this episode developed Gon and Killua... from Killua revealing his backstory to their "match" against Netero, it was just a really fun episode that did an amazing job at building up these two characters from early on. Four - Episode 105: Komugi's backstory and explanation of why she bets her life in every gungi game is just beautiful. I love everything about that scene, and Meruem's reaction is a huge moment for his character. Three - Episode 112: When Pitou races to the king after the invasion, only to find Meruem holding Komugi's limp body with Netero and Zeno just watching... I get chills 100% of the time. But then when Meruem asks Pitou calmly to heal Komugi, and the music swells as tears roll down Pitou's face... and it's honestly one of the most emotional character moments in the show for me. Not just for Meruem, but I feel like it completely changed the way I saw Pitou for the rest of the arc. Two - Episode 108: The ending where Meruem saves Komugi and first realizes that he truly cares about her is one of the most beautiful and emotional moments in the show... but everything leading up to it is SO good too. The game they play, Komugi's awakening... and most importantly when the king asks for her name, and can't remember his own. The scene plays this so well, and then his whole conversation with the royal guard afterwards is SO well written. Every character has their own unique motivation and feelings, and Meruem in particular has such a well written duality of conflicting instincts. One - Episode 146: This is probably the "most obvious" of these choices, but I haven't seen it in most peoples' top five that I've talked to. It's awesome start to finish, with Gon finally meeting his father, Parristan's victory and games (especially that moment where he looks truly sad about Netero), and EVERYTHING with Killua and "something". The last third of this episode probably makes it the most emotional for me other than maybe 116 and 135.

WRITING.TITLE: For the record, I love Greed Island.
One of the worst things about season 8 is that I truly feel like Dany's eventual antagonistic role could have been one of the greatest character arcs of all time.
WRITING.TEXT: She starts off by having her abusive brother sell her to a tribal warlord for his political gain, and has an amazing rise to power overcoming tons of obstacles (including the death of her husband and unborn son). She starts a huge crusade against slavery and not only gains a huge army and three dragons, but thousands of followers who LOVE her. All the while having a flair of the Targaryen "fire" in her. Especially in the books, we see a real conflict in her as she realizes she needs to embrace that side of her to get what she wants. If the final setbacks and blows to her were written better, and her character's decline MADE SENSE (as I'm sure it will in the books, with Aegon's plot along with Martin's deep care for character development) it would be an amazing arc. To have someone be such a focal character who is well rounded with noble intentions and real flaws try so hard to do the right thing that WE see her as what is basically the main protagonist... and have it hurt her over and over until her flaws undo her and create the final antagonist. I sincerely feel like THAT arc, along with what we've seen from Dany so far in the books, could potentially be a candidate for the best antagonist of all time. But the show not only spoiled this endgame, but rushed it so much that they butchered this transition to the point where it made no sense and just felt like a betrayal of the character. They sabotaged Martin's creative vision, Emilia Clarkes painstakingly hard work and brilliant performance, and our overall experience of one of the most prominent character arcs in all of fiction itself because they were "ready to do something else". Its frustrating to get a poor ending to a show we cared so much about, but to know what COULD have been in regards to this character straight up hurts me.

WRITING.TITLE: It's crazy how much hints and foreshadowing of what is to come can affect me when rewatching the anime.
WRITING.TEXT: It's one of my favorite things about a re-watch. Quite a few episodes will hint at what's to come, particularly in the Chimera Ant arc, and while some may find it cheesy I love the way some of them make me feel when I fully know the road ahead. The one that fucking hits me 100% of the time: Komugi walks up to Meruem for the first time, and the narrator says that the King has no idea how much she will "influence his fate". WRITING.TITLE: There's not some secret checklist that a movie has to complete to be a "horror film".
WRITING.TEXT: This is something I've been thinking a lot about lately, though I'm definitely not the first to bring it up. I have a friend that doesn't "hate" horror movies, but it's pretty obvious that he looks down on them a bit as a whole. The thing is, though, that when we come across one that he *does* enjoy, he likes to default to one of my least favorite sentences- one that we've all heard: **"but it's not really a horror movie, it's more of a psychological thriller."** It doesn't bother me at all that they label the film as a "psychological thriller", a lot of the time it is. The root of the problem for me is the *way* that the sentence is used, as a "justification" of sorts for liking the movie at all. A lot of people seem to feel "above" liking a horror film, but for some reason this term feels better to them. The truth is that one genre doesn't cancel out the other. Most films, especially the *good ones*, are a blend of multiple genres. In fact, the combination of psychological thriller and horror is extremely common, much like the relationship of fantasy and adventure. Often when my friend (other people I've noticed as well) make this claim I genuinely feel like the movie is **both**, and that they may have some bias towards the term "horror movie". When I hear people say this, it makes me wonder: *"What exactly do you think a horror movie is?"* I sometimes think people like that assume that a horror film has to be about a psychopath or demonic being that murders everyone in gruesome ways. Or that the moment the movie delves into psychological plots or themes, it immediately transcends the horror genre to become something else. "Horror" just isn't that specific or exclusive. To me, a horror movie is a movie that is designed to be "scary" as a **whole**. Any film can have some scary scenes or moments, but if the atmosphere of the movie is intended to inspire fear that's when I consider it to be a horror movie. Researching the definition of a "horror movie" brought up pretty much the same idea- if not even more vague than my own take. Obviously this leaves a lot of room for variance within the genre, especially keeping in mind that most movies don't just fall under *one label*. Horror movies can typical "slasher films" or ghost stories, but they can also be comedies, dramas, arthouse pictures, and of course, psychological thrillers. Most of the people on this sub would agree that there are some AMAZING horror films out there, but no matter how many movies of quality and substance are released people still seem to discredit the potential of the genre. I do think it's gotten a little better recently, and hopefully it continues to do so. But I wish people would realize that horror is **extremely** diverse, and that a horror film can be great without necessarily being a "psychological thriller". Rant-thing over.

WRITING.TITLE: I despise not being able to live alone.
WRITING.TEXT: I'm probably going to come across as a shitty person, maybe I am. I have a few close friends, and I really do care about them. I live with two of them (although one often doesn't stay at the house). That said, I really enjoy being alone most of the time. Way more than other people seem to, and the older I get the more I feel this way. The truth is, I've come to find that people tend to annoy me in most situations. This isn't a "I'm better than them" type of thing, it's just that having to keep up conversation, mutually planning activities together, and dealing with human drama just drains the ever loving fuck out of me, and I'd rather spend my time with my dog, reading/writing, listening to music, relaxing outside or watching movies. I have hobbies, I go to work, but in my free time I've just found that nothing is more appealing to me than being on my own. I enjoy spending time with my friends on occasion, but most people just want to be around each other all the time. Human's are social creatures supposedly, but I just feel like it doesn't apply to me. I can never fathom why people want to be around each other so much. And my friends get their feelings hurt because I don't want to hang out several times a week, and that just creates more drama I don't want to deal with. Then there's the fact that I am not financially in a position to live on my own, so I live with one of my friends (and financially this situation is near impossible to beat where I live, because they are renting the home from a family member). And they will invite friends over all the time and I'll have no idea. And that doesn't bother me, it's their house too... but no one seems to understand that someone pounding on my door shouting "YOOOO GET OUT HERE LETS CHILL" is NOT what I had planned on or felt up to that day. And then when I get really anti-social, people always seem to stand in the Kitchen talking when I want to grab something to eat. And they always try to rope me into long and drunken conversations I have no interest in, so I just go without. And I end up REALLY bitter, and I hate that. And I know this is a character flaw of mine. I know I should want to be around people more, but from the bottom of my heart I just don't. And it scares me sometimes, because while I would love to find a romantic partner (I've been single for many years now), I feel like it's possible I'll never find one if I stay like this. But when everyone I know just seems to want to be around each other 24/7, drink so much that they cannot stop talking and have no clue what they are even talking about anymore, I just can't help it if I'd rather spend a quiet day alone most of the time. I really just wanted to get this rant off my chest. I don't hate people, and I do care about my friends. It's just concerning how much of my free time I want to spend alone, and yet that's truly how I feel.

WRITING.TITLE: So many large parties make me sick
WRITING.TEXT: Is it a hive mind thing that so many parties of 15+ just become total assholes that don't for one second consider the employees they are shitting all over at all? I've had some large parties that have been great, don't get me wrong, but I don't know if it's luck or an actual pattern but most of the time if there are more than 12 people they are a nightmare to deal with and take up a large portion of your time and section only to absolutely fuck you on the tip. I've been thinking about this a lot thanks to a party from a week or so back, and it's like they were going through a checklist of everything they could do to be difficult. So I work at a breakfast diner that is only open from 2:00 PM. Apart from me never having really been an early riser, I've gotten used to it because the schedule is honestly great - no late nights ever, and no going back and forth between opening and working in the evening. It's consistent, shifts are usually 8-9 hours at the longest. Since we close so early, we are used to being on a wait pretty close to when we close, and we are also used to being there late due to finishing up with the late-comers and then having to do sidework. Even being used to this, though, this party was fucking insane. So they call us, a place that closes at 2:00pm, and said there would be 35 people coming at 1:30. Of course that is great for our sales for the day, and we are 100% a corporate restaurant, so management approved this in a heartbeat. Most employees weren't happy about it, but as long as the party was on time it wasn't the end of the world. There would still be thirty minutes until close, and large parties can be turned an hour or so... so weren't expecting it to be anymore ridiculous than usual. The first person got there at 1:55. Yep, the first person in the party of 35 people got there 5 minutes before closing, 25 minutes after they had agreed to have the full party there. And I swear, they never showed up more than two or three at a time, and people were still coming at 2:45pm. We had 2 servers taking care of them (myself included) with other people helping, but everybody was ordering on their own, paying on their own, and having their own "issues" with the food that needed correcting. We had people sending back food they "didn't like" and ordering entirely different meals well after 3:00pm. And a few of them were expecting to have their bill the minute they finished, and were expecting us to get them in and out of there while we were spending hours trying to help the rest of the party. Most of them were pretty rude the entire time, I think only a couple of them ever said "thank you" at all, and "please" was way out the window. They were not only running me and their other server around like crazy, but anyone else who dared help us and set foot in that room got worked to death as well. And this is no exaggeration, about 20% or more of them had some issue with the food they ordered and wanted to change something or order another dish entirely. It was a damn nightmare, and it wasn't until about 4:00 that most of them had finished and cashed out. They didn't leave, though. They stood around a table that was *trashed*, not just because they were messy but because they gave us very little time to pre-bus... and whenever we tried, they told us not to. So they just stood there, talking and taking pictures. We started to try and clean up around them, and they told us to stop. They told us to give them some space, and they would be gone "soon". That was the thing that pissed me off the most. We were already there hours past closing and had so much to clean up, and they somehow got the idea that we shouldn't be able to clean up while they were still there. When they finally left and all of the separate tips were added up, it was less than 10% overall. We weren't out of the building until well after 5:0pm, as we had to clean up after them and wait until all their silverware was done. One of the worst things is that management never decided that that the party of that says was arriving too late, or stood up to them when they walked all over us. To any managers out there: I know it's crucial to get your sales as high as possible. I've been in that position myself. But there is a point where you can't let customers treat your staff like this, and if a party that large arrives when you are pretty much closed, I think it's reasonable to tell them that it is past the agreed upon time and we will be close before a party that large can be taken care of. And I know most people here are in the industry, but if you are ever in a large party going out to eat please think of the employees who are BUSTING THEIR ASSES to make sure you have a good time, and try to get the rest of your party to act like civilized human beings. This party was over a week ago and I'm still upset about it. **tl;dr - party of 35 says they will arrive 30 minutes to close, and the first person shows up at 5 minutes to close. They continue to arrive in waves over the next hour, and treat the staff like shit. They run everyone to death, not just their own servers, and send a large portion of their food back, ordering different entrees long after we were supposed to close. They all payed and ordered separately, and a couple of them expected to be cashed out immediately.** **They finally finish, and stand around talking and taking pictures for about half an hour. They rudely tell us not to pre-bus or clean until every last one of them is gone. After they finally leave, and we are there cleaning up after them LONG after we close, we find that their added up tips are less than 10%.** **Thank you for letting me rant.**

As I've listened to Daron's music with Scars more and more, I've become really aware of how much of it does have a style distinctly different from System of a Down. Sure, there are songs that really do feel like System songs without Serj, such as Stoner Hate, Angry Guru, Dictator, and so on (and I still really enjoy those songs). But listening to songs like Talkin Shit, Hungry Ghost, Babylon, or 3005... It has so much less "metal" than System and veers more into a very specific style of "rock" that you don't really hear anywhere else. Even songs like They Say and Guns Are Loaded feel very different from the music Daron did with System, and while you can definitely find similarities I feel like they have that signature type of "careless rock vibe" that is synonymous with Scars on Broadway. I know some of those songs were likely going to be done with System, but I have a feeling they would have come out VERY different if they had. But while the band has some similar elements to System (and yeah some songs have a lot of similar elements), it has it's own sound that's viable on it's own. I like Rage Against the Machine more than Audioslave, but I still feel like listening to Audioslave sometimes. It's the same here, I may like System more overall, but there are plenty of times where I feel like listening to Scars more. I just wish more people wouldn't give it up instantly as soon as they hear that Serj isn't singing. That's all. And to any casual fans on this sub who haven't listened to Scars on Broadway, you really should. I know I just went on and on about how Scars is more than just a System "spin-off" (and it really is more), but they're still worth checking out for anyone into SOAD. WRITING.TITLE: Ten reasons you should watch "The Clone Wars", the animated series.
WRITING.TEXT: I realize this is [r/StarWars](https://www.reddit.com/r/StarWars/), and that most of you have probably already seen the show. But I love writing little things like this, and I do it all the time. I was just thinking about the things I enjoy in the show, I ended up writing this out. I just figured I'd share it here for the fun of it - and if I can turn even just a single person on to the show and have them enjoy it, all the better. **WHY YOU SHOULD WATCH #8220;THE CLONE WARS #8221;, THE ANIMATED SERIES** The Clone Wars is an animated #8220;kid #8217;s show #8221;, and it admittedly feels like it in the first few episodes. However, as the show goes on, it starts to feel less and less like a show for children and more like #8230; well, *Star Wars*. That #8217;s not to say that Star Wars isn #8217;t for children in general, but this saga has always had an #8220;ageless charm #8221; that appeals to anyone, adult and child alike. And when the show gets going, The Clone Wars is no different. It genuinely feels like a natural part of the Star Wars universe, and it only gets better as it goes on. It #8217;s a must watch for fans of Star Wars, and here are ten reasons why: **10.** **A massive expansion of the Star Wars universe and its lore -** One of the best things about Star Wars has always been its vast and fascinating universe, and a show like The Clone Wars has a lot more time to explore new parts of that. There are new worlds, technologies, characters, mystical forces (pun intended), creatures, and more information on the history of the universe that those who have only seen the movies are missing out on. **09. The War Itself -** Something that the prequel trilogy kind of glossed over a bit was the actual Clone War. The war only begins at the very end of the second film, and only really serves as a plot device in the third as it comes to an end. We never really get to see the majority of the war with all its battles, strategies, political challenges, and most importantly the comradery and livelihood of the soldiers. This changes with The Clone Wars, which devotes nearly 50 hours to all of this. You get a much better idea of how massive this war is and how it affected those who lived through it, plus you get a massive chunk of the Star Wars story to boot. **08. The Clones -** One major highlight of the shows is the clones themselves. They are handled very well, and cease to be just faceless soldiers that we know nothing about. They may be clones, but they are still individuals. They have their own personalities, strengths, and even have their own #8220;style #8221; that sets them apart from each other visually. Some even abandon the war to pursue their own dreams, or even betray the republic out of self interest. But for the most part, they share a sense of unity despite their differences, and they really feel like a family. A few of them become truly fascinating characters, and getting to know these soldiers really enhances the story of this war. **07. The Jedi Council -** Another thing that the show gets to devote more time towards is the massive cast of characters in Star Wars, including the Jedi Council. You not only get to see more of how they operate, but you get to see more of the characters who were mostly in the background during the films. It #8217;s always cool to see the Jedi in action, and some of the Jedi that we hadn #8217;t seen much of are really interesting characters with a lot of potential #8230; potential that this show gets to explore. **06. More of Anakin #8217;s Transition -** The films can only show so much, and while Attack of the Clone foreshadows Anakin #8217;s fall to the dark side quite a bit, most of his actual transition takes place in the third film. Taking place in between the two movies, you not only get to see more of this, but it has more of an impact. You get to see how close Anakin and Obi-Wan get, and how great of a warrior Anakin is despite the fact that he #8217;s a bit of a hot-head. It also does a better job than the films in showing the deep relationship he has with Padme. All of this adds to give more weight to Anakin #8217;s inevitable turn (simultaneously making it more believable), and the little moments of the show that hint at this fate are really cool. **05. Obi-Wan is a Boss -** Something we all already know. Obi-Wan is just awesome, and is easily one of the best characters in the entirety of Star Wars. Being one of the most important characters in The Clone Wars, Obi-Wan gets a lot of time to shine over the course of the show #8230; both as a character, and as a capable general of the war. **04. Tie-Ins with the Films -** The show is also filled with references, easter eggs, and even straight up connections to the films and other portions of Star Wars canon. I won #8217;t go into spoilers, but it #8217;s safe to say that fans who have seen the rest of the saga will enjoy certain bits of this show. And even when it isn #8217;t directly correlating with what we see in the films, but the show is constantly providing additional background on the places, characters, and events that we have seen in the films. **03. Palpatine #8217;s Manipulation of the Republic and the War -** We know from the film #8217;s that the entire war was a construct of Palpatine and his rise to power. The Clone Wars shows more of this, and provides a deeper look into the government and its central players during the war. It #8217;s cool to see the pieces moving towards what ultimately happens in Revenge of the Sith, and knowing how Palpatine is manipulating everyone before they know it is very entertaining. **02. A Deeper Look and the Confederacy of Independent Systems -** In the prequel trilogy, the CIS doesn #8217;t get much focus. It #8217;s interesting to see how much they are being played by Palpatine just like the Republic, even if they have very naturally opposing values as well. Also, there are interesting characters that play a big part in the show that are never featured in the films. **01. It #8217;s More Star Wars -** It #8217;s over 40 hours of Star Wars story that is generally well received. What more do you want?

WRITING.TITLE: Hunter X Hunter might be my favorite story. Ever. From any medium.
WRITING.TEXT: I've known for **years** now that HxH is very special to me, and that it has both impressed me with its writing and reached me emotionally in a way that not many shows, movies, or books have done. But the more I think about it lately, I think it was the perfect story for me personally. It has: * Fantastic characters, like **tons** of them, all with a sense of wholeness and real development. * A well realized world that still has so much more potential for imagination and discovery. * Amazing writing when it comes to protagonist and antagonistic roles, and is filled with gray characters with their own specific motivations * A general unpredictability and a subversion of expectations that not only persists throughout the story, but doesn't feel like ass-pulls. It's organic and enhances the story. * A sense of journey- this one is something that I've always loved in shows... it felt like a HUGE adventure that started simple, became massive, and then came full circle. * A perfect balance of light and dark within the story. Enough positivity that you can reflect on the happy parts of the story in a nostalgic way, but it can also get dark and bleak enough to reflect the harshness of reality and at times break your heart. * For an action/adventure story, there are some truly beautiful moments. * It's a story that is still going, and has potential to be a "never-ending story", which is not only awesome because any more material is welcome but because it allows the imagination to keep living in this world. BUT this is truly impressive because it does have a great ending point (where the 2011 anime leaves off) that wraps up a lot of what the original story set out to do. It's a great duality of the world continuing to go on but still getting some closure. * All the other details: the intricate and unique power system that enhances the characters and allows for such detailed and strategic battles, the themes that are incorporated into the story (from morality, war, politics, friendship, loss, trauma, and so much more), and particularly in the anime the animation, sound design/OST and voice acting. That's all, sorry for the fanboy rant. I just love this story more as time keeps passing, and I felt like ranting. Carry on.

I was really young and all my friends were smoking, so despite all this I just kept trying it... which may not have been the smart thing to do, but I'm actually glad I did. Because for me, weed has gotten SO MUCH better for me over the years. I get a lot more of the "relaxed" vibe it's known for after developing a little more of a tolerance, but I'm still able to get a fair amount of the "psychedelic" effects as well- a combo that mixes very well. I can still get a little anxiety if I smoke too much, but it's not nearly as bad as it was and it's also very easy to avoid. I just don't go crazy with my usage. I smoke every day, but I don't smoke a lot at once and I spread it out throughout the day... though a bit more at night. I also don't use bongs anymore. I found that the high I get from bongs is more prone to giving me anxiety, plus I hate coughing from smoke (like REALLY coughing that is). I smoke weed to relax after work or spark some creativity, and hacking my lungs up and getting a high that makes me tense is just counter productive. I've gotten very confident in my smoking habits, despite that even in my late 20's people still seem to have that "nah fuck that its just weed HIT THAT SHIIITT". I know what I want, and weed is amazing for me- but only if I don't abuse it. And when I talk about the psychedelic effects of weed, it really does hit me that way, I'm not just a huge light weight. I LOVE hallucinogens, everything from dissos to psychedelics and I am very experienced. I've tripped hundreds (and hundreds) of times with some pretty heavy ass doses in the mix, so it's not that I just don't know what "real" psychedelic effects are like. While it obviously isn't as strong as any of those substances, weed does have those effects for me too, and I've found that weed is more likely to make me tense or anxious at high doses than LSD, shrooms, mescaline or any other psyche.

WRITING.TITLE: The more I think about it, the more I'm okay with the series wrapping up Gon's story and focusing on other characters. Just not quite yet.
WRITING.TEXT: Long post incoming. TL;DR for *most of it* at the bottom. The general consensus seems to be that Gon will return to play a major part in the story again at some point... but it has also been speculated that his arc is finished and that he will not be a main focus again, which is an idea some people are on board with. For the most part, this doesn't seem to be due to a dislike of Gon's character, just a sense of completion in regards to his arc as well as a level of respect for the series to wrap up a main character's story and continue on with others. I've always felt that whatever Togashi decides to do I'll most likely be on board, but for a while I've still kind of wanted Gon to return to the spotlight again at *some point.* And to a degree I still feel that way, but lately all of this has made me realize that it could be cool to see Gon's journey as *the main character* wrap up in a sense, at least eventually. This is a rich world filled with interesting characters to follow, and if Gon's story comes to a natural conclusion I think that HxH could find new potential in carrying on with the world and other characters... which in a way has always been the focus. The thing is, I don't think Gon has finished his arc quite yet. He has accomplished what he set out to do in chapter one/episode one by finding his father and discovering why he left to be a hunter. This does wrap up his story *as we have known it* so far and makes for a great resting place for both the 2011 anime and for anyone who doesn't plan on reading the manga. And while I think it works as an ending, in the context of this story and its continuation I don't think that should be the very end of Gon's journey as a focal point in the series. One of the major themes in this tale is the idea that life goes on, people form connections and split off on their own paths, and everyone is just a small part of the grand scheme of life. This story is and always has been about the journey of these characters and of life. *Enjoy the little detours. To the fullest. Because that's where you'll find the things more important than what you want.* This theme makes it very appropriate to move on from Gon and focus on new characters, but it also explains why I think there should be at least a little more focus on him. Part of what makes this "enjoy the journey" motif work so well is that all of these characters have very specific paths and goals ahead of them. This world feels real and lived in because no matter who we are following, we know that the other characters are still living their lives and doing their things. Except that right now, Gon is an exception. His character is in a sort of limbo. I feel like we very well may have reached the emotional climax of his arc, but as of right now he has not only lost a major connection the major events of this story by losing his nen, but he also has no specific goals at the moment. He's kind of just sitting around at whale island not really doing anything. On the surface, it could seem like his lack of direction is a good reason his time as a main character could be concluded, but I don't think that feels right. If Hunter X Hunter really decides to wrap his story up (which it still very well may decide not to), I think we need another arc with his heavy involvement. The actual Dark Continent could be really good for this because of the specific ties to his family and ancestry that the arc may potentially have. That's not the reason he needs more time, though. I think to leave his character off on a satisfying note, he needs to find a new purpose and long-term goal. Kind of in the same way that Killua had to discover what he wanted over the course of the story so far. I think if we have him take part in one more arc in a significant way and he discovers what he wants to do with his life now that he found his father, the story could truly pull off the act of removing him from the spotlight- at least in a major way. We met him as a head strong young boy who wanted to become a hunter and discover what it means to be one, as well as find his father and learn what it meant to him. Gon became a hunter, and through his adventures he not only learned what that truly means but he also learned a lot about life itself and made some personal connections along the way. When he finally met his father, he not only learned what he had wanted to learn but Ging reaffirmed the importance of having a direction for the sake of the journey. What could potentially take Gon's arc full circle is to discover a new path to take, so that even if we aren't following him anymore we know that he's off on another adventure. The beautiful thing about Hunter X Hunter is that this massive world and unpredictable story allow for so many possibilities. I think this new turn for Gon's character should happen either way, but it would mean that future arcs could follow him on his new journeys and it could also allow his time as a main character to come to an end. If the latter were to happen, he could still play a part in certain arcs as a side character, which might be cool to see. There could be a time jump down the road, and it could be cool to see an aged and more experienced Gon from the perspective of another character. This could potentially apply to all of the "core" characters, like Killua or especially Kurapika. Kurapika has such a specific arc that just doesn't have the longevity to go on forever... once his story his completed the story could easily move on from him (not that I necessarily want him gone lol). If way down the road all four of the "mains" have wrapped up the majority of their arcs, the story could possibly rebirth itself with new focal characters. Maybe even a new series, like the jump from Dragon Ball to Dragon Ball Z. It could be really cool to see Gon, Killua, Kurapika, and Leorio take on roles similar to characters like Netero, Kite, Morel, Ging, or Silva. That's just rambling at this point, though. Who knows where this story is going, the writing works in a way that it could do all of this well or just avoid all of that (and that's under the heavy assumption that Togashi will get nearly that far with it). The main idea here is that I think with Gon's story, Hunter X Hunter has come across the possibility of doing what many shounen are unable to do- concluding a main character's story in a satisfying way while allowing the overall story to continue. And I think the best way to do that is to give the character an emotional resolution, but also a purpose for that character going forward. It not only keeps that character feeling "alive", but fits with the theme of Hunter X Hunter. It also gives the story an "ending" to the characters we've been following while possibly rebranding the face of HxH going forward. Who knows what could happen, mostly I'm just thinking out loud. **tl;dr - Gon's story in Chimera Ant and Election arcs could possibly serve as an emotional climax to his character arc, and at the least it shows that this can be achieved for our main characters. I'm on board if Togashi wants to keep Gon as a main character in the future, but if not I think it could work well too. That said, I think we need a little more in order to wrap up Gon's major story in a satisfying way. He needs a new goal after he has accomplished becoming a hunter and finding his dad. The same way Ging continuously has something he's after, Gon too needs a purpose. That way, he can go on in the background like all of the other HxH characters do whether we see him or not. This also leads to new possibilities, including time jumps and new iterations of Hunter X Hunter as we know it. While Gon is the closest to this possibility and is the main focus of this post, this could happen down the road with the other core characters as well.** **We could even get a new version of the story (like Dragon Ball to Dragon Ball Z) where the main four are far more experienced, and serve as interesting side characters to new main characters who have their own adventures and growth to accomplish.**
